question_text:
A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has hypertension and his father died of testicular cancer at the age of 51 years. He does not smoke or drink. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. He takes no medications. His immunization records are unavailable. He works as a financial consultant and will go on a business trip to Mexico City in 6 weeks. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.7°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.4 g/dL

Leukocyte count
9800/mm^3

Platelet count
168,000/mm^3

Serum

 Glucose
93 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has hypertension and his father died of testicular cancer at the age of 51 years. He does not smoke or drink. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. He takes no medications. His immunization records are unavailable. He works as a financial consultant and will go on a business trip to Mexico City in 6 weeks. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.7°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.4 g/dL Leukocyte count 9800/mm3 Platelet count 168,000/mm3 Serum Glucose 93 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: Considering that this patient's immunization records are unavailable and he will soon travel to Mexico, he needs to be vaccinated against several common illnesses.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate vaccine for a patient traveling to Mexico.

answers.explanation_why: Malaria chemoprophylaxis consists of the preventive administration of certain drugs (e.g., atovaquone-proguanil, mefloquine). Currently, the risk of malaria for US travelers to Mexico is very low. Mexico City is considered malaria-free. Therefore, the CDC does not routinely recommend the use of antimalarial drugs for individuals traveling to Mexico except for travelers going to the very South or some states near the Pacific coast.

Vaccination against rabies is indicated after exposure with a presumably infected animal (e.g., dog, bat) or for individuals who are at high risk of exposure, which include veterinarians and laboratory workers working with the rabies virus. International travelers to countries where the disease is endemic or where there is a low availability of vaccines (e.g., countries in Africa, South America, Southeast Asia, remote locations) should also receive the vaccine. This patient is going on a business trip, so he will not be in any remote locations for a long period of time.

As of 2017, a live oral cholera vaccine has been approved by the FDA. Vaccination against vibrio cholerae is indicated in travelers going to countries in which cholera infections are reported regularly or where a cholera outbreak is occurring. Although there has been a cholera epidemic in Mexico in the past, the risk for this business traveler is very low as long as he follows simple preventative measures (water and food hygiene).

Immunization against yellow fever is recommended for international travelers ≥ 9 months of age who plan on visiting endemic regions in South America or Sub-Saharan Africa. Because the disease is not prevalent in Mexico, this recommendation does not apply to this patient.

Areas with moderate to high prevalence of hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection include most parts of South America, Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe, Mexico, and Central America. Travelers to these areas should receive an HAV vaccine (ideally ≥ 2 weeks before traveling). Individuals who are due to travel to these areas in < 2 weeks require both an HAV vaccine and immune globulin, which should be injected at different anatomical sites at the same time. Because HAV is transmitted mainly via the consumption of food or water that has been contaminated with feces (e.g., shellfish), travelers should also be advised to follow primary preventive measures such as washing hands, boiling or chlorinating water, and avoiding raw food.

As of 2006, routine immunization against HAV is recommended for all children in the US older than 12 months.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician in June for a routine check-up. She has chronic back pain and underwent an appendectomy at the age of 27. Her last mammogram was 6 months ago and showed no abnormalities. Her last Pap smear was 2 years ago and unremarkable. A colonoscopy 5 years ago was normal. She regularly attends water aerobic classes and physical therapy for her back pain. Her mother died of breast cancer last year and her father has arterial hypertension. She is married and has two children. The patient recently got back from a cruise to Mexico where she celebrated her 40^th wedding anniversary. She takes a multivitamin daily and uses topical steroids. Her immunization records show that she has never received a pneumococcal or a shingles vaccine, her last tetanus booster was 6 years ago, and her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages every weekend. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (160 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician in June for a routine check-up. She has chronic back pain and underwent an appendectomy at the age of 27. Her last mammogram was 6 months ago and showed no abnormalities. Her last Pap smear was 2 years ago and unremarkable. A colonoscopy 5 years ago was normal. She regularly attends water aerobic classes and physical therapy for her back pain. Her mother died of breast cancer last year and her father has arterial hypertension. She is married and has two children. The patient recently got back from a cruise to Mexico where she celebrated her 40th wedding anniversary. She takes a multivitamin daily and uses topical steroids. Her immunization records show that she has never received a pneumococcal or a shingles vaccine, her last tetanus booster was 6 years ago, and her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages every weekend. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (160 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: The correct choice is recommended in all patients over 50 years by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate vaccine for an immunocompetent adult over 50 years of age.

answers.explanation_why: Osteoporosis screening is performed with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA). The bone density scan is recommended for postmenopausal women older than 65 years of age, or younger postmenopausal women with a pathological fracture or other risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., positive family history).

The CDC recommends pneumococcal vaccination for adults ≥ 50 years of age. However, the polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) is typically recommended after administering a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, which this patient has not yet received.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). A colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last colonoscopy 5 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.
A Pap smear is recommended every 3 years in women 21–65 years of age (or even better for patients 30–65 years of age, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years). This woman had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago.

Because influenza viruses are constantly evolving, the influenza vaccine composition is reviewed, and a newly updated vaccine is released (and recommended) for every flu season (∼ Oct.–Apr. in the northern hemisphere). This patient should return again in the early fall for an influenza vaccine.

The CDC currently recommends the recombinant zoster vaccine for the prevention of herpes zoster (shingles) and its related complications. The recombinant zoster vaccine (administered in 2 doses, 2–6 months apart) is recommended for all immunocompetent adults ≥ 50 years of age, regardless of a history of shingles, and for adults ≥ 19 years of age who are or will become immunodeficient or immunosuppressed due to disease or therapy.

Additionally, this individual should receive pneumococcal vaccination with a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination dressed in a vampire costume. He is on his way to a Halloween party at an assisted-living facility in a suburb of Boston, where he works as a patient care attendant. He feels well. He has a history of hypertension that is well controlled. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 2 months ago during a routine examination. His current medications include lisinopril and metformin. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient's screening colonoscopy at the age of 55 years was normal. He smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 15 years ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Measurement of hemoglobin A_1c obtained 2 months ago was 7.6%. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination dressed in a vampire costume. He is on his way to a Halloween party at an assisted-living facility in a suburb of Boston, where he works as a patient care attendant. He feels well. He has a history of hypertension that is well controlled. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 2 months ago during a routine examination. His current medications include lisinopril and metformin. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient's screening colonoscopy at the age of 55 years was normal. He smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 15 years ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Measurement of hemoglobin A1c obtained 2 months ago was 7.6%. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This 58-year-old man comes for a follow-up examination in the fall (on Halloween in Boston) and requires standard health maintenance recommendations for his age and risk group.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for a patient with diabetes during flu season.

answers.explanation_why: The American Diabetes Association recommends twice yearly hemoglobin A_1c (HbA_1c) testing for patients with diabetes who have stable, controlled glucose levels and quarterly testing for patients with uncontrolled glucose levels. This patient's HbA_1c was 7.6% (typical goal is < 7%) 2 months ago, and it should be rechecked in 1 month. HbA_1c gives information on the 3-month average glucose concentration in the blood, and it is premature to recheck it at this visit.

Annual influenza vaccine is recommended during the flu season (October–April in the Northern Hemisphere) for all individuals aged 6 months and older unless contraindicated. The influenza vaccination helps prevent influenza and its complications, especially in vulnerable populations like older adults, very young children, pregnant women, and individuals with chronic medical conditions. This patient with diabetes would particularly benefit from receiving the influenza vaccine because he is at higher risk of developing complications. Because he works at an assisted-living facility, he is also at increased risk of contracting and spreading the infection.

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurement is a screening strategy for prostate cancer. Current guidelines for screening with PSA measurement are controversial. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends shared decision-making regarding PSA measurement for men 55–69 years of age. Accordingly, this patient may consider screening, but there is another health maintenance recommendation that is clearly indicated.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) who have a history of colorectal cancer, like this patient, are generally recommended to obtain screening more frequently (every 5 years) and start earlier (40 years of age or 10 years before the youngest FDR's age at diagnosis). Because his last colonoscopy 3 years ago was normal, he does not require repeat screening at this time.

Annual screening for lung cancer with a low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) scan is recommended in adults aged 50–80 years with ≥ 20 pack-year smoking history. This patient has a smoking history of < 20 pack-years (1/2 pack daily for 10 years is equivalent to 5 pack-years), so LDCT is not recommended for him.

question_text: The physician recommends that the patient receive an influenza vaccine. The patient becomes nervous and reports that he has never received an influenza vaccination because of an allergy to eggs. The allergy was diagnosed many years ago after he developed hives upon eating scrambled eggs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: The physician recommends that the patient receive an influenza vaccine. The patient becomes nervous and reports that he has never received an influenza vaccination because of an allergy to eggs. The allergy was diagnosed many years ago after he developed hives upon eating scrambled eggs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate influenza vaccine for a patient with a history of egg allergy.

answers.explanation_why:
Most influenza vaccines are made from viruses grown in chicken eggs, raising the concern that allergic reactions might occur in those with a history of egg allergy. However, studies show that individuals with confirmed egg allergy can safely receive the influenza vaccine. According to the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), egg allergy of any severity is not a contraindication for influenza vaccines. All vaccines should be administered in settings where treatment can be given for an acute allergic reaction. No special precautions beyond this standard are required for the administration of influenza vaccine to patients with egg allergy regardless of allergy severity. An influenza vaccine is contraindicated in individuals who meet the diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis following previous administration of the vaccine or following exposure to a component of the vaccine other than egg protein.

Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive either the recombinant influenza vaccine or the inactivated influenza vaccine.

answers.content: Perform skin prick testing for egg allergy
answers.explanation_why: Although skin testing before administration of the influenza vaccine was suggested for patients with a history of egg allergy in the past, it is no longer recommended. Even a confirmed allergy against egg proteins is not a contraindication for vaccination. Skin testing is recommended for evaluation of patients with a history of allergy to the vaccine itself (which may be caused by a component other than ovalbumin such as preservatives) or latex from gloves.

Influenza immunoglobulins are an experimental treatment for patients with active influenza infection. There is not sufficient data to support the effectiveness of the treatment, and it is not considered an effective form of prophylaxis.

answers.content: End the examination without additional measures
answers.explanation_why: This patient would most likely benefit from a different recommendation. Ending the examination now would provide no benefit to the patient.

Oseltamivir can also be used for chemoprophylaxis of influenza in certain groups of patients (patients at high risk of complications of influenza, nonresponders to vaccination) after exposure to an infected patient. However, the CDC does not recommend routine use of oseltamivir for chemoprophylaxis of influenza.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician in May for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He underwent right inguinal hernia repair 6 months ago. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of serious illness. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and metoprolol. He received the zoster vaccine 1 year ago. His last colonoscopy 7 years ago showed no abnormalities. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 9 years. He drinks two to three alcoholic beverages on weekends. He is allergic to amoxicillin. He lives in Seattle and is scheduled to visit Australia and New Zealand in 2 weeks to celebrate his 25th wedding anniversary. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician in May for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He underwent right inguinal hernia repair 6 months ago. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of serious illness. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and metoprolol. He received the zoster vaccine 1 year ago. His last colonoscopy 7 years ago showed no abnormalities. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 9 years. He drinks two to three alcoholic beverages on weekends. He is allergic to amoxicillin. He lives in Seattle and is scheduled to visit Australia and New Zealand in 2 weeks to celebrate his 25th wedding anniversary. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: This patient seems to be in good health overall. There is only one concern in the southern hemisphere in May: “Winter is coming.”
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for patients traveling to the southern hemisphere.

answers.content: Low-dose CT scan of the chest
answers.explanation_why: A low-dose CT scan of the chest may be used to screen for lung cancer. Most societies recommend an annual low-dose CT scan for active smokers 50–80 years of age who have a 20 pack-year or longer smoking history. This patient has an 18 pack-year smoking history.

The influenza vaccine (either live-attenuated or inactivated) is recommended every year during flu season, from October to April in the northern hemisphere and April to October in the southern hemisphere. The composition of each vaccine is adjusted for the hemisphere in which it is given, which may not always be antigenically identical. Despite providing only partial immunity in these cases, the influenza vaccine in the northern hemisphere typically provides protection against the main viruses that are circulating in other parts of the world. Therefore, vaccination of patients who have not received the influenza vaccine during the influenza season is recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, and World Health Organization at least 2 weeks prior to travel. Although a US-licensed influenza vaccine for the southern hemisphere can be given to patients prior to travel, it is generally not commercially available and the vaccine for the northern hemisphere is used.

A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan may be performed to screen for osteoporosis. In patients with no other risk factors, a DEXA scan is recommended for women at 65 years of age. However, the United States Preventive Services Task Force does not currently recommend screening for osteoporosis to prevent osteoporotic fractures in men. In addition, this patient does not have any risk factors (e.g., corticosteroid use, history of heavy drinking) or previous history (e.g., bone fracture following minor trauma) to suggest osteoporosis.

Abdominal ultrasonography may be performed to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm in men 65–75 years of age who are or were smokers. This patient should undergo an abdominal ultrasound in 3 years, but it is not indicated at this time.

The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 7 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

A cardiac stress test evaluates how the heart responds to physical stress. Indications for cardiac stress testing include chronic stable angina and exertional symptoms (e.g., palpitations, syncope), none of which this patient has. Cardiac evaluation may also be indicated for patients with risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension). However, routine studies (e.g., an ECG) are usually indicated before proceeding to cardiac stress testing. A different management step is more appropriate for this patient who is scheduled to visit the southern hemisphere.

question_text: A 1550-g (3.3-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, at 33 weeks' gestation. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy was complicated by iron deficiency anemia. The mother has no other history of serious illness and she received all routine immunizations. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She does not drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by placenta previa. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding immunization for this newborn?
content_preview: A 1550-g (3.3-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, at 33 weeks' gestation. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy was complicated by iron deficiency anemia. The mother has no other history of serious illness and she received all routine immunizations. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She does not drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by placenta previa. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding immunization for this newborn?
hint: Preterm infants are to receive all recommended vaccinations as per their chronological age (the time elapsed after birth) unless contraindicated. Gestational age does not play a role in determining the timing of the regimen.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate timing for DTaP vaccination in preterm infants.

answers.content: Diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine at 2 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why:
The diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine is given to children < 7 years of age as a 5-dose regimen at 2, 4, 6, 15–18 months, and 4–6 years of age, respectively. This preterm infant has no indications that would delay the DTaP vaccine, such as uncontrolled seizures or nervous system disease, and can receive the vaccine at 2 months of chronological age.

Note that the Hepatitis B vaccine would be given before the DTaP vaccine but not immediately after birth, which is the standard immunization schedule for term newborns > 2000 g of birth weight. Infants with low birth weight have weak production of protective anti-HBs antibodies, so newborns < 2000 g should receive their first dose of Hepatitis B vaccine at 1 month of age (regardless of weight at that time) or upon discharge from the hospital, whichever comes sooner. All other vaccines are administered according to the standard immunization schedule, taking the infant's chronological age into account, irrespective of prematurity.

This is a good option to consider, but it is incorrect because of one detail - the patient's weight! According to the CDC, the hepatitis B vaccine is typically given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose administered at birth, the second dose at 1–2 months, and the third dose at 6–18 months of age in children whose mothers are HbsAg-negative, such as this newborn's fully-immunized mother. However, infants with low birth weight have weak production of protective anti-HBs antibodies, so newborns < 2000 g should receive their first dose at 1 month of age (regardless of weight at that time) or upon discharge from the hospital, whichever comes sooner. This newborn currently weighs 1550-g (3.3-lb), so hepatitis B vaccine administration would not be recommended at this time.

answers.content: Haemophilus influenza type b vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a polysaccharide-protein conjugate vaccine used in infants to prevent meningitis, pneumonia, and epiglottitis caused by Hib. It is usually given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6 months. A booster dose should be given at 12–15 months. This preterm infant should not wait 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of the Hib vaccine.

answers.content: Inactivated poliovirus vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: The inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) is usually given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6–18 months. A booster dose should be given at 4–6 years of age. This preterm infant should not wait until 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of IPV.

answers.content: Rotavirus vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: The rotavirus vaccine is given as a 2-dose or 3-dose regimen, depending upon the vaccine used. The first dose is given at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6 months (if needed). This preterm infant should not wait until 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine.

answers.content: Measles, mumps, rubella vaccine at 2 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: The measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is usually administered as a 2-dose regimen, with the first dose at 12–15 months of age and the second dose at 4–6 years of age. This preterm infant needs to be at least 12 months of age to receive the MMR vaccine.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for medical clearance for a molar extraction. He feels well. He reports he is able to climb 3 flights of stairs without experiencing any shortness of breath. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and ischemic heart disease. He underwent an aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis last year. Twelve years ago, he underwent a cardiac angioplasty and had 2 stents placed. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. A mechanical click is heard at the right upper sternal border.  Prothrombin time is 30 seconds (INR = 2.5). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for medical clearance for a molar extraction. He feels well. He reports he is able to climb 3 flights of stairs without experiencing any shortness of breath. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and ischemic heart disease. He underwent an aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis last year. Twelve years ago, he underwent a cardiac angioplasty and had 2 stents placed. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. A mechanical click is heard at the right upper sternal border. Prothrombin time is 30 seconds (INR = 2.5). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Patients with prosthetic heart valves are at an increased risk for infective endocarditis (IE), particularly when undergoing dental procedures.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for infective endocarditis prophylaxis in patients with prosthetic heart valves undergoing dental procedures, and choose the most appropriate antibiotic regimen.

answers.content: Administer oral amoxicillin 1 hour before the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Antimicrobial prophylaxis for the prevention of IE is recommended for high-risk patients (e.g., patients with prosthetic heart valves, a history of IE, or an unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart defect) who undergo procedures that are likely to result in bacteremia with common pathogens of IE. These procedures include certain dental procedures (e.g., tooth extraction, routine dental cleaning), procedures of the respiratory tract that involve incision of the respiratory mucosa, and cardiac surgery with prosthetic material (e.g., prosthetic heart valves). The most commonly used antibiotic regimen is oral amoxicillin administered 30–60 minutes prior to a high-risk procedure. Alternatives to amoxicillin include intravenous ampicillin in patients unable to take oral medication and azithromycin in patients allergic to penicillin.

Echocardiography is indicated in patients with prosthetic heart valves if a change in clinical symptoms (e.g, a new murmur, new cardiac symptoms) occurs or if valve dysfunction is suspected. Echocardiography is not routinely performed before dental procedures.

answers.content: Avoid nitrous oxide during the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Nitrous oxide (NO) is a general anesthetic used for sedation and analgesia during dental procedures. Contraindications for using NO include known hypersensitivity to NO, history of vitreoretinal surgery, and intraocular gas bubbles (a treatment for retinal detachment), none of which apply to this patient.

answers.content: Discontinue aspirin and warfarin 72 hours prior to procedure
answers.explanation_why: Anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR should be continued in patients with prosthetic heart valves who undergo procedures in which only minor bleeding is expected or bleeding can be easily controlled (e.g., dental procedures, minor dermatologic procedures).

answers.content: Administer oral azithromycin 1 hour before and 2 hours after the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Azithromycin is used as a second-line agent for the prevention of IE in high-risk patients allergic to penicillin. However, this patient has no history of allergies. Moreover, antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely administered following dental procedures.

question_text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to her primary care physician for a follow-up visit to receive the fourth dose of her diphtheria tetanus acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine. She is up-to-date on her vaccinations. Three months ago, she received her first dose of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR), first dose of varicella, third dose of Haemophilus influenza type B (HiB), fourth dose of pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), and third dose of polio vaccine. Thirteen days after receiving these vaccinations, the child developed a fever up to 40.5°C (104.9°F) and had one generalized seizure that lasted for 2 minutes. She was taken to the emergency department. The girl was sent home after workup for the seizure was unremarkable and her temperature subsided with acetaminophen therapy. She has not had any other symptoms since then. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her mother is concerned about receiving further vaccinations because she is afraid of her daughter having more seizures. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 15-month-old girl is brought to her primary care physician for a follow-up visit to receive the fourth dose of her diphtheria tetanus acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine. She is up-to-date on her vaccinations. Three months ago, she received her first dose of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR), first dose of varicella, third dose of Haemophilus influenza type B (HiB), fourth dose of pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), and third dose of polio vaccine. Thirteen days after receiving these vaccinations, the child developed a fever up to 40.5°C (104.9°F) and had one generalized seizure that lasted for 2 minutes. She was taken to the emergency department. The girl was sent home after workup for the seizure was unremarkable and her temperature subsided with acetaminophen therapy. She has not had any other symptoms since then. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her mother is concerned about receiving further vaccinations because she is afraid of her daughter having more seizures. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: The patient's history of one generalized seizure with associated fever and an unremarkable workup is consistent with a febrile seizure.
learning_objective: Recognize the indications and contraindications for DTaP vaccination, and choose the most appropriate recommendation for vaccine administration.

answers.content: Refrain from administration of the DTaP vaccine
answers.explanation_why: Administration of the DTaP vaccine typically occurs at 2, 4, 6, and 15–18 months, as well as 4–6 years. This patient is 15 months old and she should therefore receive her 4^th dose of DTaP vaccine. Contraindications for administering pertussis-containing vaccinations include severe allergic reaction to the vaccine (or to one of its components) and encephalopathy not due to any other cause within 7 days of prior vaccination. This patient has none of these contraindications for the vaccine.

answers.content: Administration of the DTaP vaccine with prophylactic aspirin
answers.explanation_why: Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) that may be administered as an analgesic, antipyretic, antiphlogistic, and antiplatelet drug. However, the administration of aspirin in children is generally contraindicated because of the risk of Reye syndrome, which is a rapidly progressive encephalopathy with concomitant liver failure that is directly associated with the use of aspirin.

answers.content: Administration of the DTaP vaccine as scheduled
answers.explanation_why: Administration of the DTaP vaccine typically occurs at 2, 4, 6, and 15–18 months, as well as 4–6 years. This patient is 15 months old and she should therefore receive her 4^th dose of DTaP vaccine. Contraindications for administering pertussis-containing vaccinations include severe allergic reaction to the vaccine (or to one of its components) and encephalopathy not due to any other cause within 7 days of prior vaccination. Uncontrolled neurological disorders should prompt a delay of the vaccination until the condition has been sufficiently assessed. Although this patient did have a febrile seizure following her last set of vaccinations, she had an unremarkable workup, suggesting an uncomplicated febrile seizure. The DTaP vaccination can therefore be administered at this time.

answers.content: Administration of the DTaP vaccine with valproic acid
answers.explanation_why: Valproic acid is an anticonvulsant that is used to treat epilepsy. This patient had a febrile seizure, which typically ends spontaneously and does not require any treatment. Her febrile seizure was likely not related to vaccination administered 2 weeks earlier.

answers.content: Administration of a reduced-dose DTaP vaccine
answers.explanation_why: A reduced dose of the DTaP vaccine may lead to inadequate protection and immune response. The evidence that such a practice would help individuals with a prior reaction to a vaccine has been disputed, so a reduced dose of DTaP is not recommended. Additionally, the patient's febrile seizure was likely not associated with the DTap vaccine administered 2 weeks earlier.

question_text: A 21-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother noticed deformities in both of his legs since he started walking independently. He has been healthy apart from an upper respiratory tract infection 6 months ago. He was delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. His 6-year-old sister was treated for developmental dysplasia of the hip. He can kick a ball and say a 2-word phrase. He plays well with other children at his day care. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40^th percentile for height and 50^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows closed anterior and posterior fontanelles. The knees do not stay together when both the feet and ankles are placed together. The gait is unremarkable. The mother is concerned that he has a growth disorder. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 21-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother noticed deformities in both of his legs since he started walking independently. He has been healthy apart from an upper respiratory tract infection 6 months ago. He was delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. His 6-year-old sister was treated for developmental dysplasia of the hip. He can kick a ball and say a 2-word phrase. He plays well with other children at his day care. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows closed anterior and posterior fontanelles. The knees do not stay together when both the feet and ankles are placed together. The gait is unremarkable. The mother is concerned that he has a growth disorder. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This 21-month-old child has genu varum (bow-leg) deformity.
learning_objective: Recognize genu varum as a normal finding in children ≤ 2 years of age, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin D supplements are used to treat rickets. While rickets can cause the genu varum deformity, as seen in this patient, as well as the genu valgum deformity, the underlying vitamin D deficiency results in softening of all bones, which leads to delayed closing of the fontanelles, impaired growth (usually < 10^th percentile for height), and further bone deformities. This child has closed fontanelles and displays normal growth and development.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Genu varum is a normal finding in children ≤ 2 years of age and typically improves as the infant learns to walk and bear more weight on the lower extremities. Knee alignment becomes neutral at about 18–24 months of age and turns into a genu valgum deformity (knock-knees), which should resolve by age 7. This 21-month-old's development has been normal thus far, and he has met all the age-appropriate milestones. He has a normal gait and shows no signs or symptoms of an underlying pathological condition (e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, fever, limb swelling). Reassurance and regular follow-up examinations are recommended to measure the intercondylar distance and to document the expected spontaneous resolution.

Rigid bracing of the hip in abduction is an appropriate treatment for children < 6 months with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Most cases of DDH are detected during newborn screening or well-child examinations. If left untreated, dysplasia of the hip results in severe gait abnormalities (e.g., Trendelenburg gait), and/or increasing adduction contraction of the hip (coxa vara deformity), with a compensatory genu valgum deformity. However, this patient has an asymptomatic genu varum deformity. Additionally, surgical treatment, and not hip bracing, would be the appropriate treatment in children > 18 months of age.

In patients with genu varum deformity, an x-ray of the lower extremities is only obtained if pathological varus is suspected. It can help to determine the underlying disease, showing evidence of Blount disease, rickets, skeletal deformities (e.g., developmental dysplasia of the hip), or a neoplasm of the leg. However, this 21-month-old has shown normal signs of development thus far, has no gait abnormalities, and shows no signs or symptoms of an underlying pathological condition, e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, fever, or limb swelling. If bow legs are still present at 3 years of age, imaging studies are indicated to evaluate for underlying pathology.

images.title: Rickets of the lower extremities
images.description: X-ray legs (AP view) of a 2-year-old child with ricketsDeficiency in mineralization has resulted in bowing of the legs (genu varum; indicated by dashed lines). Excess nonmineralized osteoid at the metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification has produced widening of the epiphyseal growth plate (examples indicated by green overlay) along with metaphyseal splaying (examples indicated by red lines), cupping (yellow line), and fraying (examples indicated by blue overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Bracing of the lower extremities is the appropriate treatment for children with Blount disease. Although Blount disease can also manifest with bow legs that become apparent once the child starts walking, it can usually be differentiated from physiological varus deformity during physical examination, as it manifests in a lateral thrusting gait (i.e., the knee of the affected leg shifts outward each time weight is placed on it) and internal rotation at the proximal tibial metaphysis (palpable prominence). This child does not have a proximal tibial deformity and he has a normal gait, making Blount disease unlikely.

Surgical management (e.g., hemiepiphysiodesis, tibial osteotomy) is reserved for children with a persistent pathologic genu varum deformity despite appropriate medical management (e.g., after vitamin D supplementation in a child with rickets). Hemiepiphysiodesis enables guided growth by selectively interrupting the growth plate unilaterally. This patient has no signs or symptoms indicating a pathologic genu varum deformity (e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, gait abnormalities).

A biopsy of the bone might be indicated in patients with clinical features and/or imaging suggesting a bone tumor (e.g., Ewing sarcoma, osteosarcoma). Rarely, a neoplasm can cause asymmetric bone growth, manifesting as a unilateral (rather than bilateral) varus or valgus deformity. Usually, malignant bone tumors are associated with localized bone pain, swelling, and, in some cases, fever and/or night sweats. However, this patient has an asymptomatic bilateral genu varum deformity. Additionally, if a bone tumor were suspected, an x-ray would be the initial test of choice and would be performed prior to biopsy.

question_text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of changes in her sleeping habits. She says that she has been gradually sleeping less over the past couple of months. It takes her 20–25 minutes to fall asleep each night, and she wakes up earlier in the morning than she used to. On average, she sleeps 5–6 hours each night. She says that she has also been waking up several times per night and needs about 20 minutes to fall asleep again. She feels mildly tired in the afternoon but does not take any naps. Her husband reports that she does not snore. She takes a 45-minute walk with her husband and their dog every other day. The patient drinks two cups of coffee each morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she appears cooperative with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of changes in her sleeping habits. She says that she has been gradually sleeping less over the past couple of months. It takes her 20–25 minutes to fall asleep each night, and she wakes up earlier in the morning than she used to. On average, she sleeps 5–6 hours each night. She says that she has also been waking up several times per night and needs about 20 minutes to fall asleep again. She feels mildly tired in the afternoon but does not take any naps. Her husband reports that she does not snore. She takes a 45-minute walk with her husband and their dog every other day. The patient drinks two cups of coffee each morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she appears cooperative with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Changes in sleep architecture occur naturally with aging. Sleep disorders (e.g., depression, obstructive sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome, and GERD) should be also considered if patients are having trouble sleeping.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management for an elderly patient with changes in sleep architecture.

answers.explanation_why: Sleep restriction can be used in patients with chronic insomnia in order to reduce sleep latency. This patient's sleep latency is within the standard deviation of normal, and therefore this technique is not likely to be significantly beneficial.

Flurazepam can be prescribed for insomnia in patients under 65 years of age. However, flurazepam and other long-acting benzodiazepines are on the Beers list of medication that is potentially inappropriate for patients > 65 years of age due to an increased risk of delirium, falls, and motor vehicle crashes. Since this patient is 74 years old, and her sleep changes are likely part of the normal aging process, flurazepam is not indicated.

Melatonin is an important hormone for sleep onset, and melatonin levels decrease with aging. In theory, melatonin should decrease sleep latency, but studies have shown its effect size to be small and potentially clinically insignificant. Furthermore, this patient's sleep latency is within the standard deviation of normal (i.e. < 30 minutes), and it is unclear how much benefit she would receive. A trial of melatonin could be indicated if sleep latency onset increased in this patient.

Changes in sleep architecture that occur naturally with aging are best managed with reassurance and sleep hygiene counseling. Changes include increased sleep latency, longer light stages of sleep with increasing frequency of nighttime awakenings, decreased time in the deep sleep phase (stage 3), shorter REM phases, as well as earlier bedtimes and morning awakenings, all of which can make individuals feel more tired. While such changes may indicate disorders (e.g., advanced sleep phase disorder) and merit treatment, this patient is most likely experiencing normal changes in sleep that occur with aging.

The sedating side effects of diphenhydramine can help patients with increased sleep latency to fall asleep. However, most patients become tolerant to this side effect over the course of a few days. Furthermore, diphenhydramine is on the Beers list of medication that is potentially inappropriate for patients > 65 years of age due to its anticholinergic effects that can precipitate delirium, constipation, dry mouth, and urinary retention. Therefore, diphenhydramine should be avoided in this 74-year-old patient.

Cognitive and behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is the treatment of choice in patients with insomnia disorder. CBT-I combines cognitive therapy, stimulus control, and sleep restriction therapy, sometimes with the addition of relaxation training. Although difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep as well as early morning awakening with the inability to return to sleep are features of insomnia, this patient does not have impaired daytime functioning, which rules out this diagnosis.

Antidepressants, such as trazodone can be used to treat insomnia, especially in patients suffering from depression. This patient's sleep changes are likely related to normal aging, and she lacks the evidence of depression (e.g., restricted affect) for trazodone to be indicated.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for bedwetting. He went 2 months without wetting the bed but then started again 6 weeks ago. He has been wetting the bed about 1–2 times per week. He has not had daytime urinary incontinence or dysuria. His teachers report that he is attentive in preschool and plays well with his peers. He is able to name 5 colors, follow three-step commands, and recite his address. He can do a somersault, use scissors, and copy a square. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for bedwetting. He went 2 months without wetting the bed but then started again 6 weeks ago. He has been wetting the bed about 1–2 times per week. He has not had daytime urinary incontinence or dysuria. His teachers report that he is attentive in preschool and plays well with his peers. He is able to name 5 colors, follow three-step commands, and recite his address. He can do a somersault, use scissors, and copy a square. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Recommendations for managing nocturnal enuresis depend on the child's age.
learning_objective: Recognize the normalcy of nocturnal enuresis in children under 5 years old, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: An enuresis alarm is a moisture sensor placed in underwear and triggers an alarm upon micturition with the purpose of waking the patient. This conditioning trains children to wake up before urinating, thus preventing enuresis. Enuresis alarms are the first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis in children who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., frequent voiding, evening fluid restriction, motivational therapy). Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis. Enuresis alarms are not indicated in this patient at this time.

Bladder training exercises involve practicing holding in urine after drinking water or waiting as long as possible to void during the day in order to expand bladder capacity and train pelvic muscles. This strategy is uncomfortable, trains children to not respond to the sensation of a full bladder, and has been shown to be ineffective.

Along with behavioral modifications (e.g., frequent voiding, evening fluid restriction), motivational therapy with a star chart or other reward systems is considered first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis. Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet the criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis and therefore does not require motivational therapy.

Nocturnal enuresis is defined as involuntary nighttime voiding of urine for ≥ 3 months in children aged ≥ 5 years. Since bedwetting is considered normal in children aged < 5 years, this boy's parents can be reassured that no further management is required at this time.

Desmopressin therapy is indicated for nocturnal enuresis after initial therapies of behavioral modification (e.g., evening water restriction, regular voiding, motivational therapy) and enuresis alarms have failed. It can also be used as an alternative first-line intervention to enuresis alarms in families who desire rapid and/or short-term improvement. Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, desmopressin therapy is not indicated in this patient.

Urinalysis should be performed when a patient is diagnosed with nocturnal enuresis to help rule out underlying causes such as urinary tract infections, diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, or proteinuria (suggestive of kidney disease). Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis and therefore does not require urinalysis. Moreover, he does not have any other symptoms, e.g., fever, weight loss, dysuria, urgency, or daytime incontinence, that might suggest an underlying disease.

question_text: A 4-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned that he is losing weight. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz); he currently weighs 2830 g (6 lb 4 oz). Pregnancy was uncomplicated. He passed stool and urine 8 and 10 hours after delivery. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth and feeds 11–12 times daily. His mother says she changes 5–6 heavy diapers daily. Examination shows an open and soft anterior fontanelle. Mucous membranes are moist. Capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned that he is losing weight. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz); he currently weighs 2830 g (6 lb 4 oz). Pregnancy was uncomplicated. He passed stool and urine 8 and 10 hours after delivery. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth and feeds 11–12 times daily. His mother says she changes 5–6 heavy diapers daily. Examination shows an open and soft anterior fontanelle. Mucous membranes are moist. Capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn has lost ∼ 5% of his weight since birth.
learning_objective: Recognize normal neonatal weight loss, and choose the most appropriate management for a healthy exclusively breastfed newborn.

answers.explanation_why: Checking serum electrolytes would be a good measure if dehydration was suspected, in which case hypernatremia would be a likely finding. However, an open and soft anterior fontanelle with no diarrhea and/or lethargy means that dehydration is extremely unlikely.

Soy-based formula is indicated for infants with galactosemia, lactase deficiency, or cow milk protein allergy. Since this child has no symptoms that would indicate a pathology (diarrhea, excessive weight loss, dehydration, fatigue, lethargy), there is no need to switch to a soy-based formula.

Checking serum electrolytes would be a good measure if dehydration was suspected, in which case renal function tests (e.g., serum creatinine and urea nitrogen) could reveal more information about the cause of dehydration (e.g., impaired water reabsorption). However, an open and soft anterior fontanelle with no diarrhea and/or lethargy means that dehydration is extremely unlikely.
Solid food should not be introduced before about 4 months of age, as the infant's digestive system cannot yet handle it.

Adding cow's milk-based formula can be considered if weight loss is prolonged and/or excessive. This neonate has lost ∼ 5% of weight since birth, which is well within the normal limit of < 7% for exclusively breastfed neonates aged ≤ 5 days.
For neonates aged ≤ 5 days, daily weight checks are indicated if weight loss exceeds 7% or if the weight is not regained after five days.

A weight loss of < 7% is normal in exclusively breastfed neonates in the first five days of life. The weight loss is the result of reduced intake and urinary excretion of excess fluid. This patient's physical examination findings are consistent with those of a healthy newborn (e.g., soft anterior fontanelle, moist mucous membranes, capillary refill time < 2 seconds); therefore, breastfeeding can be continued. The weight is then gained back by the age of 10–14 days by drinking breast milk and/or formula. This patient has only lost ∼ 5% of weight, which is still well within the normal limits.

question_text: A 4-year-old African American girl is brought to the physician because of multiple episodes of bilateral leg pain for the past 4 months. The pain lasts up to an hour and occurs primarily before her bedtime. Occasionally, she has woken up crying because of severe pain. The pain is reduced when her mother massages her legs. She has no pain while attending school or playing. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8900/mm^3 and platelet count is 230,000/mm^3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year-old African American girl is brought to the physician because of multiple episodes of bilateral leg pain for the past 4 months. The pain lasts up to an hour and occurs primarily before her bedtime. Occasionally, she has woken up crying because of severe pain. The pain is reduced when her mother massages her legs. She has no pain while attending school or playing. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8900/mm3 and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This 4-year-old girl presents with episodic, bilateral lower extremity pain that only occurs in the evening and at night, a normal physical examination, and an unremarkable complete blood count.
learning_objective: Recognize growing pains, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Testing for antinuclear antibodies is indicated in the diagnostic workup of autoimmune diseases such as juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Autoimmune diseases show varying degrees of joint involvement, including pain, swelling, erythema, stiffness, and/or reduced range of movement. Systemic symptoms, such as fever, fatigue, and weight loss are also common. This patient has none of these features.

Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a common finding in patients with infection (e.g., septic arthritis), inflammation (e.g., juvenile idiopathic arthritis), and malignancy (e.g., Ewing sarcoma). Although this girl's leg pain could result from any one of these conditions, the absence of fever, joint swelling, and fatigue make them unlikely etiologies.

Hemoglobin electrophoresis is the gold standard for diagnosing sickle cell disease (SCD). In the US, SCD is most commonly seen in individuals of African American descent. This 4-year-old girl has no features of SCD, such as anemia, or a history of vaso-occlusive crises (i.e., episodes of severe bone or abdominal pain that last hours to days). Moreover, bone pain due to SCD occurs throughout the day and does not diminish with activity. Finally, screening for SCD at birth is mandatory in all states and would therefore most likely already have been detected in this patient.

Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist used to treat Parkinson disease, as well as restless legs syndrome (RLS). RLS manifests with a recurrent urge to move the legs that is relieved by movement and worsened by rest. The urge often increases at night and may be accompanied by pain and a sensation of pins and needles. This patient has no history of an urge to move her legs and instead describes severe pain, which is not consistent with RLS.

Nafcillin is the drug of choice for the empirical treatment of osteomyelitis, which most commonly occurs in children ≤ 5 years of age. Acute osteomyelitis manifests with localized pain that worsens with movement, and possibly fever and malaise. Recurrent episodes of pain may present though with chronic osteomyelitis. Regardless, both types show swelling, erythema, warmth, and/or tenderness on examination, which are not present in this patient.

Sufficient vitamin D is especially important in children, since deficiency can lead to bone deformities (rickets), including bending of the long bones, distention of bone-cartilage junctions (e.g., of the knees), and softening of the occipital bones. Deficiency also causes hypocalcemia, which can lead to paresthesias, twitching, or dysrhythmias. Although this child's pain could be explained by vitamin D deficiency, she does not show any other signs consistent with vitamin D deficiency.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: An x-ray of the lower extremities in patients with bone pain can be used to assess for possible fractures and bone tumors. Since this patient has no history of trauma or worsening pain with activity, a trauma-related cause is very unlikely. Additionally, a bilateral presentation is not consistent with either trauma- or tumor-related conditions.

MRI in patients with bone pain is indicated to assess possible tumors for size and the extent of soft tissue and bone marrow involvement. Although bone tumors are associated with bone pain that worsens at night, a bilateral occurrence would be very unlikely. In addition, MRI is usually performed after an initial x-ray.

Growing pains most commonly occur in children 3–12 years old and manifest with episodic, bilateral pain that predominantly affects the lower extremities (shins, calves, thighs, popliteal fossa). The cramping pain most commonly occurs at the end of the day or during the night, ranges from mild to severe, and can awaken the child from sleep. Symptoms typically resolve by the morning and are not present during the day or during periods of activity. Growing pains is a clinical diagnosis because physical examination and diagnostic imaging show no abnormalities. Management consists of analgesics and massages, and reassuring patients and their parents of the condition's benign nature.

question_text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of her short stature. She was born at term, and her birth length was normal. She has not yet attained menarche. Her mother is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and her father is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall. She is at the 3^rd percentile for height and 40^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 2. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of her short stature. She was born at term, and her birth length was normal. She has not yet attained menarche. Her mother is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and her father is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall. She is at the 3rd percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 2. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: Further questioning will likely reveal a family history of delayed growth. However, both parents are of normal height now.
learning_objective: Recognize constitutional growth delay, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.content: Measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor concentration
answers.explanation_why: Serum insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels are measured to evaluate patients with short stature for growth hormone (GH) deficiency. While patients with congenital GH deficiency usually also have a normal birth length, they are often already symptomatic in the neonatal period, with hypoglycemia and prolonged jaundice. In addition, IGF-1 levels should only be evaluated in patients with slow growth (e.g., downward deviation of growth curves, change in percentiles) or with extremely short stature (< 0.6^th percentile).

answers.content: Measurement of serum LH, FSH, and testosterone concentrations
answers.explanation_why: Measurement of sex hormones (LH, FSH, estradiol/testosterone) is useful in the differential diagnosis of delayed puberty and/or primary amenorrhea if an underlying chronic disease or hormonal abnormality is suspected. However, there are no abnormalities in this patient aside from her short stature. Although she has not reached menarche at the age of 14, the development of secondary sex characteristics (i.e., breast and pubic hair development at Tanner stage 2) suggests another diagnosis.

Genetic karyotyping can be used to diagnose chromosomal abnormalities such as Turner syndrome. While patients with Turner syndrome also have a female phenotype, short stature, and delayed puberty, other characteristic signs of the condition are absent in this patient (e.g., a webbed neck, shield chest, cardiac and renal malformations). Furthermore, although Turner syndrome cannot be completely ruled out in this patient, the condition is rare, and more common causes of short stature should be excluded first.

answers.content: Measurement of serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration
answers.explanation_why: Hypothyroidism in childhood may manifest with a decrease in growth velocity or short stature in the absence of other associated features (e.g., constipation, hair loss, bradycardia). Although hypothyroidism may also cause delayed puberty, a different initial test is required to identify the underlying causes of short stature in an otherwise healthy patient. Additional testing (e.g., celiac serology, thyroid function tests) is warranted if the child is extremely short (< 0.6^th percentile) or if the history and physical examination are consistent with a specific disorder.

answers.content: X-ray of the hand and wrist
answers.explanation_why:
An x-ray of the left hand and wrist is commonly used to determine bone age and should be performed in almost all children with short stature to determine whether their growth is delayed or accelerated (e.g., by precocious puberty). This patient was of normal length at birth and both parents are of normal size, which suggests a constitutional growth delay. Patients with constitutional growth delay typically have a delayed bone age and, after a brief downward shift in percentiles after birth, a constant growth rate at or below the 3^rd percentile during childhood.

Patients with constitutional growth delay present with short stature during childhood, but their delayed bone age is associated with a longer period of growth, with most ultimately reaching their adult target height. Patients and their families should be reassured, but growth and development should be monitored nonetheless to rule out any pathologies.

An MRI of the brain is used in the diagnosis of intracranial neoplasms. The mass effect of hypothalamic or pituitary tumors can cause a deficiency of growth hormone and subsequent short stature. Craniopharyngiomas are most common in children and teenagers such as this patient. However, in a tumor large enough to cause GH deficiency, visual field defects (bitemporal hemianopsia) would likely also be present. Furthermore, imaging of the brain is only indicated in patients with short stature who have an established growth hormone deficiency or are at high risk for intracranial neoplasm (e.g., history of cranial irradiation).

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has a 6-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and his only medication is insulin. Seven months ago, he was treated for an episode of diabetic ketoacidosis. He has previously been adherent with his diet and insulin regimen. He wants to join the high school soccer team. Vital signs are within normal limits. His hemoglobin A_1C is 6.3%. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has a 6-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and his only medication is insulin. Seven months ago, he was treated for an episode of diabetic ketoacidosis. He has previously been adherent with his diet and insulin regimen. He wants to join the high school soccer team. Vital signs are within normal limits. His hemoglobin A1C is 6.3%. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: Exercise-induced hypoglycemia can be a fatal complication.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate adjustment to insulin therapy for a patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus on days of exercise.

answers.explanation_why: Exercise has a direct effect on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Although exercise does not play an essential role in glycemic control in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, it can decrease the risk for cardiovascular disease, help maintain healthy body weight, and improve the overall well-being of patients. All patients with diabetes mellitus should be encouraged to exercise regularly.

answers.content: Lower insulin dosage on days of exercise
answers.explanation_why: Patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus typically have a steeper drop in blood glucose during exercise than healthy individuals, putting them at an increased risk for hypoglycemia. Exercise increases overall insulin sensitivity, which promotes glycolysis and inhibits gluconeogenesis. In addition, an exercise-induced increase in body temperature and blood flow can accelerate resorption of subcutaneous insulin deposits, therefore, injection into arms or legs that are exercised should be avoided. Lower insulin dosages (i.e., decreased by 1–2 units per 20–30 minutes of physical activity) should be administered on days of exercise. Furthermore, patients should be advised to closely monitor their blood glucose before, during, and after exercise, to watch for symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., sweating, lightheadedness), and to eat slowly-absorbed carbohydrates after exercising to prevent delayed hypoglycemia.

Metformin is used in the antihyperglycemic treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus in order to enhance the effects of insulin. However, patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus suffer from absolute insulin deficiency, making the replacement of insulin an essential part of their treatment. Metformin is not an appropriate treatment for this patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

answers.content: Increase insulin dosage on days of exercise
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus and hyperglycemic episodes, a paradoxical elevation of blood glucose can occur during exercise. This patient's current hemoglobin A_1C of 6.3% indicates appropriately-controlled blood glucose. Increasing the insulin dosage on the days of exercise would further increase this patient's risk of dangerous hypoglycemia.

Some conditions require an increase in insulin dosage, e.g., acute illness, which is associated with elevated blood glucose levels due to an acute stress reaction.

answers.content: Limit activity to 20 minutes per day
answers.explanation_why: Limiting the patient's activity to exactly 20 minutes per day is not recommended. Patients with diabetes should perform at least 150 minutes of exercise per week. Additionally, just 20 minutes of exercise could cause dangerous hypoglycemia in a patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus, which would require adjustment of his medication.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 10-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of progressively enlarging breasts bilaterally for the past 4 days. The parents report that they have sometimes noticed a discharge of small quantities of a white liquid from the left breast since yesterday. During pregnancy, the mother was diagnosed with hypothyroidism and was treated with L-thyroxine. The patient's maternal grandmother died of breast cancer. The patient currently weighs 3100 g (6 lb 10 oz) and is 51 cm (20 in) in length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows symmetrically enlarged, nontender breasts, with bilaterally inverted nipples. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 10-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of progressively enlarging breasts bilaterally for the past 4 days. The parents report that they have sometimes noticed a discharge of small quantities of a white liquid from the left breast since yesterday. During pregnancy, the mother was diagnosed with hypothyroidism and was treated with L-thyroxine. The patient's maternal grandmother died of breast cancer. The patient currently weighs 3100 g (6 lb 10 oz) and is 51 cm (20 in) in length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows symmetrically enlarged, nontender breasts, with bilaterally inverted nipples. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This newborn's condition is due to the placental transfer of maternal estrogens.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for neonatal gynecomastia.

answers.explanation_why: Testosterone supplementation is indicated in cases of hypogonadism, which can also present with gynecomastia, but it is typically diagnosed in adolescents with delayed puberty onset or in adult men with decreased libido, hot flashes, and infertility.

Neonatal gynecomastia is a common condition that occurs when maternal estrogen in the neonate's circulation stimulates glandular proliferation. This condition typically manifests with bilateral breast enlargement irrespective of biological sex. Some newborns may also present with a milky discharge (galactorrhea), which occurs when a decrease in the levels of maternal estrogen in the neonate's circulation stimulates the release of prolactin in the pituitary gland. Both gynecomastia and galactorrhea usually resolve spontaneously within a few weeks or months and do not require treatment.

Breast biopsy is only indicated in suspected pathological gynecomastia to identify the underlying cause, if physical examination, imaging, and laboratory studies are inconclusive. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (1.6 inches), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

Hormonal assays are only indicated in suspected pathological gynecomastia to identify the underlying cause and include early morning measurement of serum hCG, estradiol, testosterone, LH, and DHEA. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (> 1.6 in), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

Measurement of TSH is indicated in suspected hyperthyroidism, which may cause gynecomastia, but usually only in adults. Newborn hyperthyroidism could result from maternal L-thyroxin therapy in rare cases. However, newborns with hyperthyroidism present with a goiter, tachycardia, irritability, diarrhea, and vomiting, none of which are present in this patient.

Chromosomal analysis is only indicated when the underlying cause of breast enlargement is thought to be due to a chromosomal aberration such as Klinefelter syndrome (47 XXY), which usually becomes apparent at the onset of puberty, making it unlikely in this newborn. In addition to gynecomastia, patients with Klinefelter syndrome have a eunuchoid growth pattern, and testicular hypoplasia.

Since mammography is difficult to interpret in children and adolescents due to their increased density of the breast, ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality if a pathological breast mass is suspected in this age group. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (> 1.6 in), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

answers.content: Measurement of serum estrogen and testosterone
answers.explanation_why: Hormonal assays are only indicated in suspected pathological gynecomastia to identify the underlying cause and include early morning measurement of serum hCG, estradiol, testosterone, LH, and DHEA. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (> 1.6 in), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

Oral dicloxacillin is indicated for outpatient treatment of newborns with mastitis, which is mostly due to Staphylococcus aureus. Fullterm infants < 2 months of age with well-developed breasts due to stimulating intrauterine estrogens are most likely to develop such an infection. While this patient presents with nontender, bilateral breast enlargement and milky discharge, mastitis in infants is usually unilateral and presents with swelling, erythema, warmth, tenderness, induration, axillary lymphadenopathy, possibly pustules or bullae, and purulent discharge.
