question_text: A 14-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of short stature. She feels well overall, but is concerned because all of her friends are taller than her. Her birth weight was normal. Her father reports he had a short stature during his teenage years; he is currently 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall. The daughter is at the 2^ndpercentile for height and 35^th percentile for weight. Breast development is Tanner stage 2. Pubic and axillary hair is absent. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 11 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 14-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of short stature. She feels well overall, but is concerned because all of her friends are taller than her. Her birth weight was normal. Her father reports he had a short stature during his teenage years; he is currently 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall. The daughter is at the 2ndpercentile for height and 35th percentile for weight. Breast development is Tanner stage 2. Pubic and axillary hair is absent. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 11 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: An adolescent girl with short stature, delayed puberty, delayed bone age, and a family history of delayed growth most likely has constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP).
learning_objective: Recognize constitutional delay of growth and puberty, and choose reassurance and appropriate follow-up as management.

answers.explanation_why: Measurement blood glucose levels can be used to screen patients for diabetes. Many systemic illnesses, including diabetes mellitus, can cause a growth delay. Although, type 1 diabetes is more common in children and adolescents and can also present with delayed growth, patients typically also present with weight loss, polydipsia, and polyuria, all of which are absent in this patient. Screening for diabetes in an otherwise healthy teenager with delayed puberty is, therefore, not part of the routine workup.

Genetic karyotyping can be used to diagnose chromosomal anomalies such as Turner syndrome. While patients with Turner syndrome also have short stature and delayed puberty, they also present with other characteristic signs of the condition such as a webbed neck, shield chest, and cardiac and renal malformations, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, Turner syndrome would not explain this patient's delayed bone age.

Growth hormone (GH) therapy can be used to increase growth in children with idiopathic short stature, Turner syndrome, or GH deficiency (GHD). However, patients with Turner syndrome and idiopathic short stature disorders typically present with a bone age normal for their chronological age. Patients with GHD can have a delayed bone age and experience delayed puberty. However, in cases of GHD, either a growth delay is apparent within the first few months of life, or the associated characteristic features of acquired GHD, such as an immature (“cherubic”) fat distribution and characteristic facial features (underdeveloped nasal bridge and frontal bossing), are present. Moreover, before GH supplementation is initiated, a definitive diagnosis should be unequivocally established with hormonal assays and serial measurements of length or height. Therefore, GH treatment is not appropriate as the next step of management in this patient.

A pelvic ultrasound can be used in the evaluation of delayed puberty and/or primary amenorrhea if a pelvic mass or anatomical anomalies of the genital tract are suspected. However, this patient's physical exam found no anatomical anomalies or signs of a pelvic mass (e.g., pelvic tenderness, palpable resistance), and her delayed bone age indicates CDGP. A pelvic ultrasound is therefore not indicated in the initial workup.

Measurement of serum dehydroepiandrosterone levels can help differentiate congenital GnRH deficiency (e.g., in Kallmann syndrome) from constitutional delay of puberty. Although patients with congenital GnRH deficiency can also have delayed bone age, delayed puberty, and short stature, adrenarche occurs normally, usually leading to the development of some pubic hair which is not seen in this patient. In addition, congenital GnRH deficiency is very rare and often associated with other findings (e.g., hyposmia/anosmia in Kallmann syndrome or skeletal abnormalities such as cleft lip/palate or syndactyly). While congenital GnRH deficiency cannot be entirely excluded in this patient, measurement of serum DHEA is not indicated at this time.

Reassurance and follow-up are sufficient for patients with CDGP, which is a normal variant of growth characterized by short stature during childhood (usually below the third percentile) and delayed puberty. Affected individuals usually have a normal length at birth, but growth velocity decreases between 6 months and 3 years of age. Bone age is typically delayed by 2–4 years causing growth to take longer than usual. After a growth spurt in late adolescence, patients usually reach a normal adult height. While patients should be closely monitored to ensure that growth velocity does not decrease further, treatment is not indicated.

Further testing to rule out pathological causes should be performed in all patients with delayed puberty, who present with changes in growth velocity for at least 6 months and/or with signs of underlying disease. Testing should include a CBC, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, BUN, creatinine, liver function tests, and hormonal tests (e.g., LH, FSH, estradiol, testosterone, TSH).

An MRI of the brain can be used in the diagnosis of intracranial neoplasms. Mass effect of hypothalamic or pituitary tumors can cause a deficiency of growth hormone, LH, and FSH, which subsequently causes short stature and delayed puberty. Craniopharyngiomas are most common in children and teenagers, but a tumor large enough to cause hormone deficiencies would likely also manifest with visual field defects (bitemporal hemianopsia). Further, imaging of the brain is only indicated in patients that have established hormone deficiencies or are at high risk for intracranial neoplasm (e.g., history of cranial irradiation).

question_text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and the neonatal period were uncomplicated. The infant was exclusively breastfed and received vitamin D supplementation. She can sit unsupported and can transfer objects from one hand to the other. She babbles and is uncomfortable around strangers. She is at 40^th percentile for length and at 35^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to continuing breastfeeding, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and the neonatal period were uncomplicated. The infant was exclusively breastfed and received vitamin D supplementation. She can sit unsupported and can transfer objects from one hand to the other. She babbles and is uncomfortable around strangers. She is at 40th percentile for length and at 35th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to continuing breastfeeding, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: Mature breast milk is composed of proteins, lactose, oligosaccharides, fats, minerals, trace elements, and vitamins, as well as proteins and cells that provide passive immunity, and bifidobacteria that contribute to the infant's gut flora.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate dietary recommendation for a 6-month-old infant.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin D supplementation is recommended in infants < 12 months old who are exclusively breastfed. Nevertheless, the prevention of other nutritional deficiencies should also be addressed at 6 months of age.

answers.content: Introduce solid foods and add vitamin B12
answers.explanation_why: Infants should be introduced to solid foods at approximately 6 months of age, as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. However, foods such as meat, fish, and eggs contain sufficient amounts of vitamin B12, so that supplementation is only necessary if the mother or the child are eating a strictly vegetarian or vegan diet.

answers.content: Introduce solid foods and continue vitamin D
answers.explanation_why:
Introduction to solid foods is recommended for infants at 6 months of age (approximately) as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. Additionally, Vitamin D supplementation is recommended in infants < 12 months old who are exclusively breastfed from birth until meeting the recommended daily intake of vitamin D through diet.

The diet should be balanced, and excessive amounts of foods and drinks high in sugar (e.g., fruit juice) should be avoided to prevent childhood caries. Once a solid diet is initiated, parents should also ensure good oral hygiene (e.g., rubbing the infant's gum with a wet cloth or using pediatric toothbrushes).
Foods such as meat, fish, and eggs contain sufficient amounts of vitamin B12, so that supplementation is only necessary if the mother or the child are eating a strictly vegetarian or vegan diet.

Infants should be introduced to solid foods at ∼ 6 months of age, as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. However, solid food alone does not contain adequate amounts of all the nutrients required so that further supplementation is indicated in infants.

answers.content: Introduce solid food and cow milk
answers.explanation_why: Infants should be introduced to solid foods at ∼ 6 months of age, as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. However, cow milk should not be introduced until 1 year of age as it is poorly tolerated in infants and associated with iron-deficiency anemia and higher rates of blood in infant stool.
Cow milk should not be introduced until 1 year of age as it is poorly tolerated in infants and associated with iron-deficiency anemia and higher rates of blood in infant stool.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned that she has been talking to an imaginary friend for 2 months. The child calls her friend 'Lucy' and says “Lucy is my best friend”. The child has multiple conversations and plays with 'Lucy' throughout the day. The girl attends preschool regularly. She can hold a pencil between the first two fingers and the thumb, tells stories, and can hop on one foot. Her maternal uncle has schizophrenia. Her parents are currently divorcing. The child's father has a history of illicit drug use. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is concerned about whether the child is acting out because of the divorce. Which of the following is the most appropriate next best step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned that she has been talking to an imaginary friend for 2 months. The child calls her friend 'Lucy' and says “Lucy is my best friend”. The child has multiple conversations and plays with 'Lucy' throughout the day. The girl attends preschool regularly. She can hold a pencil between the first two fingers and the thumb, tells stories, and can hop on one foot. Her maternal uncle has schizophrenia. Her parents are currently divorcing. The child's father has a history of illicit drug use. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is concerned about whether the child is acting out because of the divorce. Which of the following is the most appropriate next best step in management?
hint: This patient's gross motor (hops on one foot), fine motor (tripod pencil grasp), and language (tells stories) developmental milestones are all appropriate for her age.
learning_objective: Recognize normal developmental behavior in preschoolers, and choose the most appropriate reassurance for the parent.

answers.explanation_why: A number of drugs such as cocaine, ecstasy, amphetamines, lysergic acid diethylamide, and phencyclidine have been associated with hallucinations in children (e.g., following accidental ingestion). Since this girl's father has a history of drug abuse, unintentional contact with these substances should be considered. However, symptoms would typically have an acute onset, would not last for two months as in this girl, and would be different in character (e.g., perception of unusual colors).

Intracranial neoplasms can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including hallucinations. However, hallucinations as a primary symptom in the absence of other signs of a tumor, such as focal symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure, are very rare.

Child Protective Services (CPS) should be informed if there are signs of abuse or neglect of a minor. Signs of abuse and neglect can be subtle and history findings of parental drug use should certainly raise concern for the child's well-being. Although patients, particularly following sexual abuse, can develop hallucinations, these hallucinations commonly cause distress rather than comfort as in this patient. Additionally, this patient's age-appropriate milestones, the absence of signs of physical abuse, and the fact that she attends preschool regularly make child maltreatment less likely.

A psychiatric consult would be indicated if an underlying psychiatric condition was suspected. While a variety of psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia or posttraumatic stress disorder can present with hallucinations, they are rare during childhood and more commonly associated with negative hallucinations (e.g., cause fear or distress). Additionally, unlike this girl, patients often show signs of abnormal development (e.g., delayed milestones).

Risperidone therapy would be indicated in a child with schizophrenia. Although children with schizophrenia typically also have hallucinations that last longer than one month and this child has a family history of schizophrenia, the condition is very rare in children, especially before puberty. Further, patients have to present with additional symptoms (e.g., delusions, disorganized behavior or speech, diminished emotions) and a decreased level of functioning in order to meet the DSM-5 criteria for schizophrenia.

Imaginary friends are relatively common in preschoolers such as this girl and occur as part of normal development. Children typically get along with these friends (e.g., consider them “their best friend”) and the imaginary figures do not cause any distress or impaired functioning. Parents should be reassured. Further evaluation is only indicated if the imaginary friends persist beyond early school age, or if the child's general behavior or development changes.

Stress factors such as the parent's divorce can cause various behavioral responses in different age groups. Preschoolers such as this girl often display magical thinking and may believe that their actions caused the divorce. They can subsequently develop unusual or odd behaviors in the hope of reconciling their parents. Parents should be advised to reassure the child that their actions had no influence on the decision to get a divorce. A counselor can assist if problems persist.

question_text: During the selection of subjects for a study on infantile vitamin deficiencies, a child is examined by the lead investigator. She is at the 75^th percentile for head circumference and the 80^th percentile for length and weight. She can lift her head up when in a prone position, but cannot roll over from a prone position. Her eyes follow objects without crossing the midline. She coos and makes gurgling sounds. When the investigator strokes the sole of her foot, her big toe curls upward and there is fanning of her other toes. She makes a stepping motion when she is held upright and her feet are in contact with the examination table. Which of the following additional skills or behaviors would be expected in a healthy patient of this developmental age?
content_preview: During the selection of subjects for a study on infantile vitamin deficiencies, a child is examined by the lead investigator. She is at the 75th percentile for head circumference and the 80th percentile for length and weight. She can lift her head up when in a prone position, but cannot roll over from a prone position. Her eyes follow objects without crossing the midline. She coos and makes gurgling sounds. When the investigator strokes the sole of her foot, her big toe curls upward and there is fanning of her other toes. She makes a stepping motion when she is held upright and her feet are in contact with the examination table. Which of the following additional skills or behaviors would be expected in a healthy patient of this developmental age?
hint: This patient has a developmental age of 2 months based on her motor milestones (can lift her head when in the prone position, follows objects without crossing the midline), speech milestones (coos, makes gurgling sounds), and the presence of a stepping reflex.
learning_objective: Recognize the developmental milestones of a 2-month-old infant.

answers.explanation_why: Infants reach out for visible objects at about 6 months of age. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months; at this developmental age, infants have their hands fisted most of the time, occasionally opening them for short periods of time.

answers.content: Responds to calling of own name
answers.explanation_why: Responding to calling of their own names usually occurs around the age of 9 months in normally developing infants. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months and is less likely to have a significant response to verbal stimuli and/or calling of her own name.

answers.content: Cries when separated from her mother
answers.explanation_why: Infants go through a normal developmental phase of separation anxiety at around the age of 9 months, which is characterized by excessive clinging to the main parental figure. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months and is unlikely to start crying when separated from her mother.

Infants gain the ability to roll over from supine to prone position at the age of 6 months. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months and is unlikely to be able to roll over from her back at this time.
Healthy 2-month-old infants typically start to recognize caregivers and exhibit a social smile.

question_text: A young girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She is at the 55^th percentile for height and at the 40^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is able to follow simple 2-step commands, such as “close your eyes, then stick out your tongue,” and half of her speech is understandable. She can say 2-word phrases and is able to name many parts of the body. Assuming normal development, which of the following milestones are expected in a patient this age?
content_preview: A young girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She is at the 55th percentile for height and at the 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is able to follow simple 2-step commands, such as “close your eyes, then stick out your tongue,” and half of her speech is understandable. She can say 2-word phrases and is able to name many parts of the body. Assuming normal development, which of the following milestones are expected in a patient this age?
hint: This patient's speech milestones are consistent with a developmental age of 2 years: approx. 50% of speech is understandable, use of 2-word phrases, and able to name multiple body parts.
learning_objective: Recall developmental milestones in a 2-year-old.

answers.explanation_why: Copying a circle when demonstrated is a cognitive skill expected at around 3 years of age. Cognitive skills expected at 2 years of age include using complex toys (e.g., switches), and playing with more than one toy at a time.

Separation anxiety usually resolves by the age of 3 years, when children willingly spend time away from their parents. At 2 years of age, and, assuming normal development, children are expected to still show signs of separation anxiety.

Kicking a ball independently is a gross motor skill expected at around 2 years of age. Other gross motor skills expected around this age include running and independently climbing stairs with both feet on each step. The fine motor skill expected for children at 2 years of age is to be able to feed themselves with a spoon. Cognitive skills expected at 2 years of age include using complex toys (e.g., switches), and playing with more than one toy at a time. See “Developmental milestones in childhood” table.
Fastening buttons is a fine motor skill expected at around 5 years of age. The fine motor skill expected for children at 2 years of age is to be able to feed themselves with a spoon.
Hopping on one foot is a gross motor skill expected at around 5 years of age.

answers.content: Holds a pencil between the first two fingers and the thumb
answers.explanation_why: Tripod pencil grasping is a fine motor skill expected at around 4 years of age. The fine motor skill expected for children at 2 years of age is to be able to feed themselves with a spoon.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her earlier pregnancy was uncomplicated. This is her 4^th prenatal visit. She had an ultrasound scan 2 weeks ago that showed a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with a 22-week gestation with no anomalies. She had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. Her blood group and type is B positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her earlier pregnancy was uncomplicated. This is her 4th prenatal visit. She had an ultrasound scan 2 weeks ago that showed a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with a 22-week gestation with no anomalies. She had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. Her blood group and type is B positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: At 24–28 weeks' gestation, screening for a condition associated with fetal macrosomia is recommended.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate screening test for gestational diabetes at 24 weeks' gestation.

answers.content: Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A and hCG level
answers.explanation_why: Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A and hCG levels (in combination with ultrasound measurement of nuchal translucency) are part of first-trimester screening for congenital abnormalities and are usually performed between 10–14 weeks' gestation.

Screening for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) with an oral glucose challenge test is recommended for every pregnant patient at 24–28 weeks' gestation, or earlier in patients with increased risk of undiagnosed type 2 diabetes (e.g., due to obesity and GDM in a previous pregnancy). Early diagnosis and treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus are important to prevent complications of this condition, including gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, and shoulder dystocia due to fetal macrosomia.

Rh antibody testing should be performed in all Rh-negative pregnant women between 28–29 weeks' gestation to screen for circulating Rh antibodies. Although screening can be performed earlier, Rh antibody testing is not necessary for this Rh-positive patient.

answers.content: Swab for Group B streptococcus culture
answers.explanation_why: Screening for Group B streptococcus (GBS) by vaginal and rectal swab is performed at 36–37+6 weeks' gestation to evaluate for colonization that could potentially lead to neonatal infection or chorioamnionitis. Women who are positive for GBS should be treated with intrapartum penicillin G, or clindamycin or erythromycin in patients allergic to penicillin.
Biophysical profile is used to screen for pregnancies where there is an increased risk of antenatal fetal death. It is generally performed after 32 weeks' gestation.
Tdap vaccination is usually performed between 27 and 36 weeks' gestation to boost maternal immunity to pertussis and to maximize the passive transfer of protective antibodies to the neonate.

question_text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. Menopause occurred 7 years ago. Colonoscopy 4 years ago disclosed no abnormalities. A serum lipid profile obtained last year was within the reference range. Two years ago, a Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus showed no abnormalities. Mammography performed 10 months ago showed no abnormalities. She is a retired university professor and lives with her husband. She has no children. Her father developed colon cancer at the age of 75 years. She has no family history of hip fracture. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A fasting serum glucose level is 102 mg/dL. Screening for depression with a validated questionnaire is negative. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. Menopause occurred 7 years ago. Colonoscopy 4 years ago disclosed no abnormalities. A serum lipid profile obtained last year was within the reference range. Two years ago, a Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus showed no abnormalities. Mammography performed 10 months ago showed no abnormalities. She is a retired university professor and lives with her husband. She has no children. Her father developed colon cancer at the age of 75 years. She has no family history of hip fracture. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A fasting serum glucose level is 102 mg/dL. Screening for depression with a validated questionnaire is negative. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This patient's history and physical examination findings do not suggest that she has a higher risk of morbidity than average.
learning_objective: Recognize the appropriate health maintenance recommendations based on patient history and screening guidelines, and choose the correct follow-up action.

answers.explanation_why: The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening mammography every 2 years in women aged 40–74 years with average risk for breast cancer. This patient had a normal mammogram 10 months ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.

Screening for lipid disorders is recommended in all adults aged 20–75 years at least every 4–6 years. In adults aged 40–75 years, the screening interval can be shortened based on the individual ASCVD risk. Given that this patient had a normal serum lipid profile 1 year ago and has no significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, or smoking), her ASCVD risk is likely low. A repeat serum lipid profile is not warranted at this time.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) with a history of colorectal cancer, like this patient, are generally recommended to obtain screening more frequently (every 5 years) and start earlier (40 years of age or 10 years before the youngest FDR's age at diagnosis). Because her last colonoscopy 4 years ago was normal and she lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), she does not require repeat screening at this time.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women ≥ 65 years of age for osteoporosis with bone measurement testing (e.g., dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry). For postmenopausal women < 65 years of age, the decision to screen should be based on an assessment of the patient's overall risk for osteoporosis. This patient has no significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), so screening is not indicated at this time.

answers.content: No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed
answers.explanation_why:
No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed at this time for this 61-year-old woman who is currently up to date with all recommended screening tests based on her age, history, and physical examination findings. The recommendations that this patient has followed include screening for cervical cancer (Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing every 5 years), colon cancer (every 5 years in patients with a first-degree relative with a history of colorectal cancer, every 10 years in the general population), and breast cancer (mammography every 1–2 years). Moreover, she does not have identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of dyslipidemia, diabetes, hypertension, or smoking) or osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), which would warrant enhanced screening for these conditions.

See “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” table.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women between 30 and 65 years of age for cervical cancer using any of the following strategies: every 3 years with cervical cytology, every 5 years with testing for high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) testing, or every 5 years with hrHPV testing in combination with cytology. This patient had a normal Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus 2 years ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.

question_text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 5 days. The first day of her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 5 days. The first day of her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has never had a mammogram. Her mother and maternal aunt died of breast cancer in their early 50s. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This patient is healthy and requires the standard screening tests for her age group and risk stratification according to USPSTF guidelines.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate cancer screening tests and intervals for a woman based on age and risk factors.

answers.content: Pap smear now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
answers.explanation_why: According to the USPSTF, a Pap smear every 3 years in individuals with a cervix who are 21–29 years of age is an acceptable screening method for cervical cancer. However, an additional test is required as a part of cervical cancer screening starting at the age of 30 years. In addition, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every year, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why: Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, this patient should now receive HPV testing along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should not be repeated annually because more frequent testing does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

answers.content: Pap smear now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why: Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years from 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening every 5 years starting at 30 years of age. However, when screening every 5 years, the protocol requires another test in addition to the Pap smear. If the additional test cannot be performed, a Pap smear should be taken every 3 years.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why: Mammography at the age of 40 years is appropriate for this patient since the USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening with mammography every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Also, the USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 5 years, mammography at age 40 years
answers.explanation_why:
The USPSTF recommends HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years for individuals with a cervix who are 30–65 years of age and a solitary Pap smear every 3 years for those between 21–29 years of age. This guidance differs from the recently updated ASCCP, ACS, and ACOG guidelines, which recommend that those aged 25–65 years undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (where available) or HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years. All guidelines recommend a solitary Pap smear every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable.

Regarding breast cancer, mammography is rarely useful in younger patients, who have naturally denser breast tissue. According to the USPSTF, breast cancer screening with mammography should be performed every 2 years between 40–74 years of age. Screening can be started earlier in patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancer. Breast cancer screening recommendations may differ between medical organizations (e.g., ACOG, ACS). Consult our table “Breast cancer screening for individuals at average risk” for the most up-to-date information on breast cancer screening recommendations.

Whenever the information required to determine the correct answer for an NBME question involves a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF recommendations.

answers.content: Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing now and every 3 years, mammography at age 50 years
answers.explanation_why: The USPSTF recommends an HPV test along with a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, starting at 30 years of age. However, HPV/Pap cotesting should be repeated every 5 years rather than every 3 years because more frequent screening does not increase the cancer detection rate and is associated with a higher rate of unnecessary colposcopies. Moreover, breast cancer screening is typically started at 40 years of age.

question_text:
A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit when she learned she was pregnant. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her mother has type 1 diabetes mellitus, and her father has asthma. Current medications include a prenatal multivitamin. She appears well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:

Alpha-fetoprotein
decreased

Unconjugated estriol
decreased

Human chorionic gonadotropin
increased

Inhibin A
increased

During counseling regarding the potential for fetal abnormalities, the patient says that she would like a definitive diagnosis as quickly as possible. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit when she learned she was pregnant. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her mother has type 1 diabetes mellitus, and her father has asthma. Current medications include a prenatal multivitamin. She appears well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show: Alpha-fetoprotein decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Human chorionic gonadotropin increased Inhibin A increased During counseling regarding the potential for fetal abnormalities, the patient says that she would like a definitive diagnosis as quickly as possible. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: On the second-trimester screening test (quadruple test), the combination of increased hCG, increased inhibin A, decreased unconjugated estriol, and decreased alpha-fetoprotein indicates a high risk of Down syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize the high risk of Down syndrome from prenatal screening results, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test for confirmation.

answers.explanation_why: Reassurance is not appropriate for a patient who has a second-trimester quadruple test result that indicates that the fetus may have Down syndrome. Patients in this situation may desire additional diagnostic testing and/or pregnancy termination. Because this patient expressed her desire to find a definitive diagnosis, further testing and counseling should be offered.

Cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) testing of maternal blood can be used to screen for fetal aneuploidies such as Down syndrome. Because of its low false-positive rate for Down syndrome, cffDNA testing is commonly used as a secondary screening test in patients at high risk (e.g., maternal age ≥ 35 years, abnormal screening results) in order to avoid invasive procedures. However, cffDNA testing is not diagnostic and fetal chromosomal analysis using an invasive test is still required to confirm Down syndrome.

Amniocentesis for fetal chromosomal analysis is the method of choice to confirm fetal aneuploidy in patients at ≥ 15 weeks' gestation and should be offered to all patients at increased risk (e.g., abnormal screening results, maternal age ≥ 35 years, previous child with a chromosomal anomaly). Complications of amniocentesis include miscarriage (< 0.5%), premature rupture of the membranes, fetal-maternal hemorrhage, and infection.

Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is one component of first-trimester screening. Although the first-trimester combined test is the earliest screening test that can be performed (at 10 weeks' gestation), the second-trimester quadruple test that this patient has undergone has greater accuracy in later gestational ages. An isolated serum PAPP-A measurement would not provide additional information.

Although chorionic villus sampling can be performed to obtain fetal DNA for establishing the diagnosis of Down syndrome, it is typically performed between 10–13 weeks' gestation and would not be the preferred confirmatory test at 16 weeks' gestation.

Ultrasound is an essential component of prenatal aneuploidy screening but is not used for confirmatory testing. It is used in first-trimester screening (nuchal translucency measurement) and subsequent second-trimester serum testing (quadruple test or triple screen), or during the integrated screening process (nuchal translucency with quadruple screening). Findings that suggest a diagnosis of Down syndrome during the second trimester include nuchal fold thickness ≥ 6 mm, intracardiac hyperechogenic focus, and structural malformations. This patient has already undergone a screening test, which was positive; pelvic ultrasound would not be used to confirm a diagnosis of Down syndrome.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: This patient's history and age determine the most appropriate recommendation at this time.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate vaccination for a sexually active young adult woman.

answers.explanation_why:
As part of the routine immunization schedule, the CDC states that two doses of the nine-valent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine should be administered six to twelve months apart to all individuals aged 9–14 years. For all unvaccinated female individuals aged 15–26 years, the CDC recommends vaccination with three doses of the nine-valent HPV vaccine at 0, 2, and 6 months. The HPV vaccine is approved by the FDA for individuals up to the age of 45 years, but it is not routinely recommended by the CDC for individuals aged > 26 years.

Condoms lower the risk of, but do not protect against, HPV infection because HPV can still be transmitted via genital skin-to-skin contact or oral sex.

For women aged between 21 and 29 years, the USPSTF recommends a Pap smear every three years. Since this patient had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago, another Pap smear is not required for nearly another two years.

The most common indication for a pregnancy test is recent-onset secondary amenorrhea in a patient of childbearing age. Because her last menstrual period was six days ago, this patient does not have amenorrhea. If this 24-year-old woman had acute lower abdominal pain, a pregnancy test would be indicated to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. However, there is currently no indication for performing a pregnancy test in this asymptomatic patient presenting for a routine pelvic examination.

Cotesting refers to simultaneous Pap smear and HPV testing. It is the USPSTF's recommended cervical cancer screening of choice for women aged between 30 and 65 years every five years. In this 24-year-old patient, the USPSTF instead recommends a Pap smear every three years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend that women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

HPV testing and a simultaneous Pap smear, known as cotesting, is recommended by the USPSTF for cervical cancer screening for patients aged 30–65 years every five years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing alone (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recent weight gain. She started a combined oral contraceptive for dysmenorrhea and acne six months ago. She has been taking the medication consistently and experiences withdrawal bleeding on the 4^th week of each pill pack. Her acne and dysmenorrhea have improved significantly. The patient increased her daily exercise regimen to 60 minutes of running and weight training three months ago. She started college six months ago. She has not had any changes in her sleep or energy levels. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lbs); six months ago she weighed 57 kg (126 lbs). Examination shows clear skin and no other abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recent weight gain. She started a combined oral contraceptive for dysmenorrhea and acne six months ago. She has been taking the medication consistently and experiences withdrawal bleeding on the 4th week of each pill pack. Her acne and dysmenorrhea have improved significantly. The patient increased her daily exercise regimen to 60 minutes of running and weight training three months ago. She started college six months ago. She has not had any changes in her sleep or energy levels. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lbs); six months ago she weighed 57 kg (126 lbs). Examination shows clear skin and no other abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Consider the causes of this patient's weight gain.
learning_objective: Recognize the likely causes of weight gain in the context of lifestyle changes, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: This woman started gaining weight around the time she started treatment with combined oral contraceptives (COC) but, despite popular belief, weight gain has not been proven to be a side effect of COC. Since the patient also started college 6 months ago and has recently intensified her training routine, her weight gain is most likely attributable to changes in eating habits and an increase in muscle mass. As the current treatment has also proven to be beneficial for her previous dysmenorrhea and acne, reassurance and advice on maintaining a healthy weight are the most appropriate steps in management.

Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are measured to diagnose thyroid disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Individuals with hypothyroidism often present with symptoms of decreased metabolic rate, including fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, and secondary amenorrhea. In the absence of any other typical features of hypothyroidism, this woman's weight gain is more likely due to other causes.

Serum testosterone levels are measured in women with suspected polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), a disorder characterized by hyperandrogenism, anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. Typical clinical features include menstrual irregularities (e.g., amenorrhea), infertility, hirsutism, obesity, and acne. Although PCOS causes acne, and the condition may also improve with combined oral contraceptive treatment, she had no other features suggestive of PCOS and only started gaining weight after treatment, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Perform a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
answers.explanation_why: A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used to diagnose elevated cortisol levels in individuals with Cushing's syndrome. Common clinical features include hypertension, central obesity, moon facies, easily bruisable skin and acne, muscle atrophy, and features of virilization in women (hirsutism, menstrual cycle irregularities). Since this woman's weight gain did not occur simultaneously with her other symptoms and she does not have hypertension, Cushing's syndrome is unlikely.

A pelvic ultrasound is performed to confirm pregnancy. Although weight gain is a symptom of pregnancy, pregnancy is unlikely since she consistently takes oral contraceptives, menstruates regularly, and her urine pregnancy test is negative.

answers.content: Switch contraceptive to a nonhormonal contraceptive method
answers.explanation_why: Switching from hormonal contraceptive methods to nonhormonal contraceptive methods is indicated in women who experience side effects or have contraindications to combined hormonal contraception (e.g., development of hepatic adenoma, increased risk of thromboembolism, estrogen-dependent tumor). Since this woman's dysmenorrhea and acne have improved since starting treatment with combined oral contraceptives (COCs) and there is no evidence that weight gain is a side effect of COCs, there is no indication to change her treatment regimen.

answers.content: Switch contraceptive to a progestin-only pill
answers.explanation_why: Progestin-only contraceptive pills are indicated in women who have contraindications to treatment with estrogen-containing combined oral contraceptives. Contraindications include estrogen-dependent and hepatic tumors, an increased risk for thromboembolic events and cardiovascular disease, cigarette smoking, acute pancreatitis, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Since this patient has no known contraindications to estrogen-containing treatment and is tolerating her current medication well, a change in treatment is not indicated.

question_text: A mother brings her 3-year-old son to his pediatrician because he is having tantrums. The boy has no history of serious illness and is on track with developmental milestones. His mother recently returned to work 2 weeks ago. She explains that, since then, her son has had a tantrum roughly every other morning, usually when she is getting him dressed or dropping him off at daycare. He cries loudly for about 5 minutes, saying that he does not want to go to daycare while thrashing his arms and legs. According to the daycare staff, he is well-behaved during the day. In the evenings, he has tantrums about twice per week, typically when he is told he must finish his dinner or that it is time for bed. These tantrums have been occurring for about 6 months. The mother is concerned her son may have a behavioral disorder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the boy's behavior?
content_preview: A mother brings her 3-year-old son to his pediatrician because he is having tantrums. The boy has no history of serious illness and is on track with developmental milestones. His mother recently returned to work 2 weeks ago. She explains that, since then, her son has had a tantrum roughly every other morning, usually when she is getting him dressed or dropping him off at daycare. He cries loudly for about 5 minutes, saying that he does not want to go to daycare while thrashing his arms and legs. According to the daycare staff, he is well-behaved during the day. In the evenings, he has tantrums about twice per week, typically when he is told he must finish his dinner or that it is time for bed. These tantrums have been occurring for about 6 months. The mother is concerned her son may have a behavioral disorder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the boy's behavior?
hint: The most important factor in differentiating normal behavior from a psychiatric disorder is ascertaining whether or not the behavior (e.g., tantrums, irritability) impairs normal, daily functioning and violates age-appropriate norms.
learning_objective: Recognize normal developmental tantrums in children.

answers.explanation_why: Autism spectrum disorder is characterized by persistent impairment in communication and social interaction and restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior. However, the daycare center reports that the child engages in normal group play and as such autism spectrum disorder cannot be diagnosed at this point.

Conduct disorder is characterized by a repetitive and persistent pattern of disruptive behavior for ≥ 12 months that violates the basic rights of others or age-appropriate societal norms or rules. This child does not display any patterns that are inappropriate for his age.

Normal development is simply the absence of any diagnosable disorder. Temper tantrums and defiant behavior are normal to a certain extent in children aged 1–3 years, as long as they neither impair normal functioning during the day nor violate age-appropriate norms. If this child were to display consistent and excessive physical aggression towards his parents, or an irritable and angry mood throughout the entire day, there would be cause for concern. But as the daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved throughout the day, the tantrums are most likely a normal part of the child's development.

Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by anger, irritable mood, and defiant behavior towards figures of authority lasting ≥ 6 months. These behaviors must impair normal daily functioning. However, this child does not display these behaviors, as the daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved during the day.

There are many criteria used to assess the level of inattention and hyperactivity and to diagnose ADHD. One of the most important criteria is that both inattention and hyperactivity must be severe enough to interfere with normal daily functioning. The daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved during the day, which means that normal functioning cannot be considered impaired, and as such ADHD cannot be diagnosed at this point.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is characterized by extreme irritability, anger, and severe recurrent outbursts of temper (verbal or behavioral) for ≥ 12 months that also impair normal daily functioning. However, as the daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved during the day, normal functioning cannot be seen as impaired, and as such disruptive mood dysregulation disorder cannot be diagnosed at this point.

question_text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with HIV 8 years ago. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. He is planning a trip to Thailand with his partner to celebrate his 35^th birthday in 6 weeks. His last tetanus and diphtheria booster was given 4 years ago. He received three vaccinations against hepatitis B 5 years ago. He had chickenpox as a child. Other immunization records are unknown. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His leukocyte count is 8700/mm^3, CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 480 cells/mm^3, and anti-HBs antibody titer is 150 mIU/mL. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with HIV 8 years ago. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. He is planning a trip to Thailand with his partner to celebrate his 35th birthday in 6 weeks. His last tetanus and diphtheria booster was given 4 years ago. He received three vaccinations against hepatitis B 5 years ago. He had chickenpox as a child. Other immunization records are unknown. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His leukocyte count is 8700/mm3, CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 480 cells/mm3, and anti-HBs antibody titer is 150 mIU/mL. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: The immunization schedule including live attenuated vaccines fully applies to patients with HIV infection and a CD4^+ count above 200 cells/mm^3.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate vaccination for an HIV-positive patient with a CD4+ count above 200 cells/mm3.

answers.explanation_why: Hepatitis B vaccine is generally recommended for all HIV-positive patients without immunity to hepatitis B. A booster dose following previous vaccination is required if the anti-HBs titer is < 10 mlU/mL. Since this patient's anti-HBs titer is 150 mlU/mL, he still has adequate immunity to hepatitis B.

The Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) live vaccine is given to select patient groups (e.g., children with a negative tuberculin skin test and continued high-risk exposure, healthcare workers on an individual basis) to prevent TB infection. However, it is no longer generally recommended in the US because of its variable effectiveness and the overall low risk of infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

In adults with a completed routine tetanus and diphtheria vaccination, booster doses are recommended every 10 years. In cases of injury with an increased risk of tetanus infection (e.g., animal bites), a booster dose is administered if the last immunization was ≥ 5 years ago. Since this patient's tetanus and diphtheria vaccination are up-to-date, no further boost is required at this point.

Vaccinations in individuals infected with HIV should follow the generally recommended immunization schedule, including for live vaccines. Adults with uncertain immunity to measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) such as those with unknown vaccination status, no laboratory evidence of immunity, or born after 1957, should be given a dose of MMR vaccine, provided the CD4+ count is > 200 cells/mm^3. Further recommendations for patients with HIV include vaccinations for pneumococcal disease and influenza (using the inactivated or recombinant influenza vaccines, as the live-attenuated vaccine is not recommended regardless of CD4+ count). The efficacy of immunization is reduced in patients with HIV infection.

The yellow fever vaccine should be administered to individuals traveling to endemic areas, including tropical Africa (e.g, Guinea, Ghana) and parts of Central and South America (e.g., Brazil, Ecuador). While live vaccines like the yellow fever vaccine can be safely administered in HIV patients with a CD4+ count > 200 cells/mm^3 and no signs of immunocompromise (e.g., presence of AIDS-defining illness), yellow fever is not endemic in Thailand.

images.title: Geographic distribution of yellow fever (risk of transmission)
images.description: The green areas indicate regions where yellow fever is endemic. The WHO recommends vaccination for travelers to high-risk areas. When traveling to low-risk areas, there is no general recommendation; however, vaccination may be considered for longer stays or if there is a high risk of exposure. Proof of vaccination may be required when traveling to or from certain countries. Consult information from the WHO or CDC before traveling.

answers.explanation_why: The standard immunization schedule should generally be observed in patients with HIV. Exceptions to this rule include a CD4 count < 200 cells/mm^3 and the presence of AIDS-defining illnesses (e.g., Kaposi sarcoma, pneumocystis pneumonia). Since none of these exceptions are present, this patient should receive the generally recommended vaccinations.

question_text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. Six years ago, he underwent a colonoscopy, which was unremarkable. He has no history of serious illness except for an episode of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis at the age of 10 years. His father died of bladder carcinoma at the age of 55 years and his brother was diagnosed with prostate cancer at the age of 61 years. The patient works at a rubber factory. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 12 years. He drinks 1–2 cans of beer per day. He takes no medications. His vaccinations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient asks what additional health maintenance measures he should consider at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. Six years ago, he underwent a colonoscopy, which was unremarkable. He has no history of serious illness except for an episode of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis at the age of 10 years. His father died of bladder carcinoma at the age of 55 years and his brother was diagnosed with prostate cancer at the age of 61 years. The patient works at a rubber factory. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 12 years. He drinks 1–2 cans of beer per day. He takes no medications. His vaccinations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient asks what additional health maintenance measures he should consider at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: This patient's individual risk factors (e.g., family history, age, sex) should be taken into account when selecting the most appropriate next step in management.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance action for prostate cancer screening in a patient with relevant risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: Urine cytology can be used in the workup for urothelial cancer. While this patient has risk factors for bladder cancer (works at a rubber factory, family history of bladder cancer, smokes cigarettes), urine cytology is not used for routine screening of bladder cancer because of its low sensitivity.

The US Preventative Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 6 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

answers.content: Discuss prostate-specific antigen assessment with the patient
answers.explanation_why:
Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurement may be considered as part of the screening process for prostate cancer, a common malignancy that is often asymptomatic in the initial stages. Current screening guidelines for prostate-specific antigen testing are controversial. The use of PSA as a screening marker is constantly questioned because of potential overdiagnosis, overtreatment, and associated complications such as negative psychological effects, erectile dysfunction, or urine incontinence. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends against any routine PSA-based screening for prostate cancer; they recommend that decisions about PSA assessment in men aged 55–69 years who inquire about screening be made based on patient preference after having received information on potential risks and benefits. The American Urological Association recommends PSA testing on a case-by-case basis in men aged 45–69 years after shared decision-making based on individual preferences. PSA testing is not recommended in men < 40 years of age.

This patient is 60 years old and he has a family history of prostate cancer in a first-degree relative; a discussion about PSA screening would be warranted. Following the discussion, PSA levels should only be obtained if the patient expresses that he wants to proceed with the screening test.

answers.content: Obtain low-dose CT scan of the chest
answers.explanation_why: Low-dose CT scan of the chest is recommended as a screening test for lung cancer in patients 50–80 years of age with a history of smoking (≥ 20 pack-years). Although this patient is 60 years old, he only has a 12 pack-year history. A low-dose CT scan would therefore not be indicated at this time.

Cystoscopy is a diagnostic procedure for bladder cancer. Although this patient has risk factors for bladder cancer (works at a rubber factory, family history of bladder cancer, smokes cigarettes), a cystoscopy would only be indicated for the evaluation of gross hematuria or microscopic hematuria in patients > 35 years of age.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Six months ago, she was vaccinated against influenza. Her last mammography 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. Two years ago, a pap smear and colonoscopy were normal. She has a history of hypertension. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50 years. She emigrated from Japan 30 years ago. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 18 years. She drinks 4–5 glasses of wine per day. She goes ballroom dancing twice each week. Her medications include enalapril and low-dose aspirin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a soft S_4 gallop. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Six months ago, she was vaccinated against influenza. Her last mammography 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. Two years ago, a pap smear and colonoscopy were normal. She has a history of hypertension. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50 years. She emigrated from Japan 30 years ago. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 18 years. She drinks 4–5 glasses of wine per day. She goes ballroom dancing twice each week. Her medications include enalapril and low-dose aspirin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a soft S4 gallop. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Excessive alcohol consumption, smoking, and low body weight are significant risk factors for osteoporosis.
learning_objective: Recognize the risk factors for osteoporosis, and choose the most appropriate screening test.

answers.explanation_why: Influenza vaccination is recommended once per year for adults and children > 6 months of age. This patient was vaccinated 6 months ago, so there is no need to revaccinate until the start of the next influenza season.

A Pap smear is recommended every 3 years until 65 years of age to screen for cervical cancer. Since her Pap smear 2 years ago was normal, there is no indication to perform the test again at this point in time.

Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry is a screening test used to diagnose osteoporosis. This screening test is recommended for all women ≥ 65 years of age. Additionally, bone mineral density assessment should be obtained for all postmenopausal women aged ≤ 65 years who have one or more risk factors for osteoporosis. This patient is up to date on all other recommended screenings and preventive measures based on her age and risk factors.

Abdominal ultrasonography is used to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This screening is recommended in men 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history. Screening can also be considered in women 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history, in individuals < 65 years of age with multiple risk factors for AAA or a family history of AAA, and in individuals 65–75 years of age with a positive family history for AAA in a first-degree relative. Based on this patient's sex, age, and risk factors, screening for a different condition using another modality is indicated at this time.

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last colonoscopy 2 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

answers.content: Low-dose CT scan of the chest
answers.explanation_why: Annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is used to screen for lung cancer in adults 50–80 years of age who have a smoking history ≥ 20 pack-years. This patient has a 9-pack-year smoking history (0.5 pack/day × 18 years) and no other risk factors for lung cancer.

A soft S_4 gallop does not warrant an echocardiogram in an elderly patient who is asymptomatic, as it most likely indicates age-related decreased ventricular compliance. Indications for echocardiogram include a palpable S_4 or symptoms concerning for acute myocardial infarction (e.g., chest pain) or heart failure (e.g., dyspnea or lower extremity edema). Moreover, a transthoracic echocardiogram rather than a transesophageal echocardiogram would be the most appropriate initial step in the workup of an abnormal S_4 gallop.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She recently moved to the area. She feels well. She has dyslipidemia treated with pravastatin. Her past three Pap smears have shown no abnormalities; the most recent Pap smear was 2 years ago. Her maternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 56 years. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 10 years ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m^2. Her pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She recently moved to the area. She feels well. She has dyslipidemia treated with pravastatin. Her past three Pap smears have shown no abnormalities; the most recent Pap smear was 2 years ago. Her maternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 56 years. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 10 years ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?
hint: This patient's dyslipidemia and overweight put her at risk of developing a chronic medical condition that can cause microvascular damage.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for diabetes mellitus screening.

answers.explanation_why: For cervical cancer screening in women 30–65 years of age, the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends Pap smears every 3 years with cervical cytology alone, every 5 years with human papillomavirus (HPV) testing alone, or every 5 years with HPV testing in combination with cytology (HPV/Pap cotesting). This 38-year-old patient had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago and therefore does not need further testing at this time.

Measurement of fasting blood glucose (FBG) concentration is routinely used to screen for diabetes mellitus (DM). Although screening recommendations for DM differ among expert groups, this 38-year-old patient with dyslipidemia and a BMI of 29 kg/m^2 meets the screening criteria of both the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) and the American Diabetes Association (ADA). The USPSTF recommends screening individuals 35–70 years of age with overweight or obesity. The ADA recommends screening all individuals ≥ 35 years of age and individuals < 35 years of age who: have overweight or obesity and ≥ 1 additional risk factor for T2DM; have a history of prediabetes or gestational diabetes; or have any risk-enhancing comorbidities (e.g., HIV infection, cystic fibrosis, post organ transplantation).

Besides FBG, other tests used to screen for DM include hemoglobin A_1C (HbA_1C) and the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Each of the following findings can be used to establish a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus: FBG ≥ 126 mg/dL, HbA_1C ≥ 6.5%, and a 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL during an OGTT.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening with abdominal ultrasonography can be considered in individuals < 65 years of age who have multiple risk factors for AAA or a family history of AAA, neither of which applies to this patient.

answers.content: Obtain low-dose CT scan of the chest
answers.explanation_why: An annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is indicated for lung cancer screening in individuals aged 50–80 years with a smoking history of ≥ 20 pack years. This patient has a smoking history of 10 pack years and therefore does not require screening at this time.

Breast cancer screening is generally not recommended before 40 years of age (except for individuals at high risk of breast cancer). Additionally, when breast cancer screening is appropriate, screening mammography is the recommended screening modality, not breast ultrasonography. Breast ultrasonography is typically reserved for individuals < 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass or other findings concerning for breast cancer.

In individuals 19–49 years of age, pneumococcal vaccination is only indicated if there are risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease. Because this 38-year-old patient only has dyslipidemia and a remote history of smoking, she does not need the pneumococcal vaccine at this time.
