question_text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician in June for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with HIV infection 3 months ago. He has been taking combined antiretroviral therapy since then. He feels well. He is sexually active with both female and male partners and regularly uses barrier protection. He does not smoke and drinks 2–3 glasses of wine on weekends. The patient did not receive any childhood vaccines besides the hepatitis B vaccine. Six years ago, he received the tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccination. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is 190/mm^3. Which of the following immunizations should be administered at this time?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician in June for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with HIV infection 3 months ago. He has been taking combined antiretroviral therapy since then. He feels well. He is sexually active with both female and male partners and regularly uses barrier protection. He does not smoke and drinks 2–3 glasses of wine on weekends. The patient did not receive any childhood vaccines besides the hepatitis B vaccine. Six years ago, he received the tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccination. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is 190/mm3. Which of the following immunizations should be administered at this time?
hint: Special attention should be paid to the selection of appropriate vaccinations in patients with HIV, especially those with a low CD4 count, which indicates severe immunodeficiency.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate immunization for an HIV-positive patient with a low CD4 count.

answers.explanation_why: Vaccination against varicella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count < 200/mm^3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm^3, he should receive this vaccine to protect him against chickenpox and shingles.

answers.content: Tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine
answers.explanation_why: The tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccination is indicated in adults who did not receive the usual schedule of vaccinations during childhood, as is the case in this patient. Booster vaccination with tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) is required every 10 years in order to maintain full immunity. However, this patient received his Tdap vaccine only 6 years ago, which means that he will not require a booster dose of the Td vaccine for another 4 years.

Annual Influenza vaccination with the inactivated or recombinant vaccine is highly recommended, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as this patient. However, he is currently being seen in the month of June, which is still too early for the influenza vaccine. For maximum protection from the influenza virus, he should receive the vaccine at a follow-up visit in the early fall. The live-attenuated influenza vaccine should not be administered to individuals with HIV infection, regardless of their CD4+ T lymphocyte count.

Vaccination against measles, mumps, and rubella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live attenuated vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count of < 200/mm^3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm^3, he should receive this vaccine.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk for infection, including with human papillomavirus (HPV). However, the same guidelines apply to immunocompromised individuals as the general population, which is that HPV vaccination is recommended in all individuals ≤ 26 years of age. While the FDA has approved the HPV vaccine for individuals up to 45 years of age, the decision to receive a vaccine after 26 years of age is established on an individual basis.

Pneumococcal polysaccharide 23 vaccine (PPSV23) is recommended for individuals aged 19–65 years who are immunocompromised (e.g., those with HIV). However, the PPSV23 vaccine should not be administered before the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, PCV15. Because this patient's vaccination history is unknown, he should receive the PCV15 now and return in at least 8 weeks to receive the PPSV23. Alternatively, individuals can be given one dose of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine PCV20 without subsequent need for PPSV23.

Patients with HIV infection or chronic liver disease are at increased risk of developing a severe disease following infection with the hepatitis A (HepA) virus. The HepA vaccine is part of the routine vaccine regimen and is recommended for all individuals between 12 and 23 months of age with a second dose administered at least 6 months later. Any adult who did not receive the vaccine and is at high risk for HepA infection or severe disease should be vaccinated. The HepA vaccine is a killed vaccine and can be safely administered even if the patient has a low CD4 T-cell count.

Risk factors for HepA infection include recent travel to an area where the virus is endemic, recreational drug use, and men who have sex with men.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother. His mother reports multiple instances over the past month when she walked into his room while he was masturbating. She is worried he may be going through some sort of “problem.” He is currently in 9^th grade. His mother says that he recently made his high school varsity wrestling team and does reasonably well in school. The patient had separation anxiety disorder at the age of 9 years, which resolved with cognitive behavioral therapy. On examination, he seems embarrassed and avoids making eye contact. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother. His mother reports multiple instances over the past month when she walked into his room while he was masturbating. She is worried he may be going through some sort of “problem.” He is currently in 9th grade. His mother says that he recently made his high school varsity wrestling team and does reasonably well in school. The patient had separation anxiety disorder at the age of 9 years, which resolved with cognitive behavioral therapy. On examination, he seems embarrassed and avoids making eye contact. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: Masturbation is considered excessive if it causes significant distress and/or interferes with daily functioning.
learning_objective: Recognize normal sexual behaviors in adolescents and reassure concerned parents accordingly.

answers.content: Advise the patient to stop masturbating
answers.explanation_why: Advising to stop masturbating can be considered for patients whose masturbation is excessive and interferes with social or occupational functioning (e.g., skipping school to masturbate). This adolescent does not seem to be affected in his ability to carry out daily activities and is succeeding academically.

Measuring serum testosterone levels should be considered in case of delayed puberty, which the patient shows no features of. Abnormal levels of testosterone are unlikely to manifest with excessive masturbation.

answers.content: Refer the patient for behavioral therapy
answers.explanation_why: Behavioral therapy can be used to treat sexual dysfunction disorders (e.g., male hypoactive sexual desire disorder, female sexual arousal disorder, genito-pelvic pain disorder). However, masturbation that does not interfere with daily functioning is not considered a sexual dysfunction disorder and does not require behavioral therapy.

Masturbation is a normal activity in individuals of all ages and is only considered abnormal if it becomes disruptive and/or impairs social or occupational functioning (e.g., skipping school to masturbate). This patient has not been affected in his ability to carry out daily activities and is succeeding academically. Therefore, masturbation should not be discouraged and the patient's mother should be reassured and counseled appropriately.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (e.g., sertraline) are indicated in patients with psychiatric disorders such as depression or generalized anxiety disorder. This patient has no features that suggest a psychiatric illness.

answers.content: Refer the patient for psychoanalytic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Psychoanalytic therapy may be useful in the treatment of certain sexual disorders, including difficulty sustaining healthy sexual relationships. However, masturbation that does not interfere with daily functioning is not considered a sexual dysfunction disorder and does not require psychoanalysis.

question_text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin. Four years ago, she underwent cholecystectomy for recurrent cholecystitis. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m^2. Her blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, with a waist circumference of 94 cm. Serum studies show:

Fasting glucose
112 mg/dL

Total cholesterol
200 mg/dL

 HDL-cholesterol

36 mg/dL

Triglycerides
170 mg/dL

Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin. Four years ago, she underwent cholecystectomy for recurrent cholecystitis. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, with a waist circumference of 94 cm. Serum studies show: Fasting glucose 112 mg/dL Total cholesterol 200 mg/dL HDL-cholesterol 36 mg/dL Triglycerides 170 mg/dL Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
hint: This patient has hypertension, abdominal obesity, insulin resistance (fasting glucose ≥ 100 mg/dL and previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes), low HDL, and moderate hypertriglyceridemia. These findings are consistent with metabolic syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize metabolic syndrome, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Risk factors for the development of central sleep apnea include a history of cardiac abnormalities, chronic opioid use, and neurocognitive deficits. Although this patient's abdominal obesity puts her at increased risk of developing obstructive sleep apnea, she has no known risk factors for central sleep apnea.

Osteoporosis is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. Although this 57-year-old patient is most likely postmenopausal, the risk of developing primary osteoporosis in a patient < 65 years of age is low. Additionally, obesity is actually a protective factor against the development of osteoporosis.

The most common complications of metabolic syndrome include cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). NASH arises independently of alcohol use and occurs due to fatty infiltration of hepatocytes, hepatocyte necrosis, and, eventually, fibrosis of the liver. This patient is at high risk of NASH due to her metabolic syndrome and, therefore, at increased risk of developing liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Metabolic syndrome is associated with peripheral vascular disease and atherosclerosis, both of which increase susceptibility to ischemic stroke. Subarachnoid hemorrhage, however, usually occurs due to trauma or aneurysm rupture; metabolic syndrome is not a known risk factor for subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease that is associated with certain human leukocyte antigen (HLA) subtypes. Given this patient's high BMI, she is at increased risk of developing degenerative osteoarthritis, but there is no known association between metabolic syndrome and development of RA.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child visit. Her father is concerned about the color and strength of her teeth. He says that most of her teeth have had stains since the time that they erupted. She also has a limp when she walks. Examination shows brownish-gray discoloration of the teeth. She has lower limb length discrepancy; her left knee-to-ankle length is 4 cm shorter than the right. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have been taken by this child's mother when she was pregnant?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child visit. Her father is concerned about the color and strength of her teeth. He says that most of her teeth have had stains since the time that they erupted. She also has a limp when she walks. Examination shows brownish-gray discoloration of the teeth. She has lower limb length discrepancy; her left knee-to-ankle length is 4 cm shorter than the right. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have been taken by this child's mother when she was pregnant?
hint: This child has dental and skeletal abnormalities that are likely the result of in utero exposure to a particular antibiotic drug. This drug inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking incoming aminoacyl-tRNA from binding to the ribosome acceptor site.
learning_objective: Recognize the effects of in utero tetracycline exposure.

answers.explanation_why: Trimethoprim is a folic acid antagonist that should be avoided in pregnancy (especially in the first trimester) because of the increased risk of neural tube defects. However, it is not known to cause the dental or skeletal abnormalities seen in this patient.

In utero exposure to sulfamethoxazole can precipitate kernicterus in neonates, which is why this drug should be avoided during pregnancy. However, it is not known to cause the dental or skeletal abnormalities seen in this patient.

In utero exposure to fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, may be associated with cartilage damage. Fluoroquinolones should be avoided during pregnancy, although their degree of toxicity has not been fully established. They are not, however, known to cause dental discoloration.

In utero exposure to gentamicin and other aminoglycosides is associated with ototoxicity in children, which is why this group of drugs should be avoided during pregnancy. However, they are not known to cause the dental or skeletal abnormalities seen in this patient.

In utero exposure to chloramphenicol is associated with gray baby syndrome, which is why this drug should be avoided during pregnancy. However, it is not known to cause the dental or skeletal abnormalities seen in this patient.

Tetracycline crosses the placenta and accumulates in developing teeth and bones because of its tendency to form complexes with calcium salts. In utero exposure can lead to discoloration of deciduous teeth and inhibition of bone growth, as seen in this patient. For this reason, tetracyclines are contraindicated during pregnancy and in children < 8 years of age.

question_text: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
content_preview: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.
learning_objective: Recognize the risk of hemorrhagic disease in newborns, and choose the appropriate supplement to prevent it.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

Fluoride crosses the placental barrier and is present in breast milk following environmental exposure. Most newborns have already accumulated measurable levels at birth. In regions where the drinking water is not fluoridated, the current recommendation is to administer fluoride to children but not before the age of 6 months due to the risk of fluorosis. Using fluoride to support dental hygiene protects against dental caries, which is not a life-threatening condition.

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Folic acid (vitamin B9), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation unnecessary. Individuals planning pregnancy should be supplied with folic acid beginning ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continuing until 12 weeks' gestation to prevent neural tube defects. Infants born to folate-deficient mothers can develop megaloblastic anemia, but this carries no immediate postnatal complication or risk of mortality.

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.

question_text: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a routine well-child examination. She is given a vaccine that contains polyribosylribitol phosphate conjugated to a toxoid carrier. The vaccine is most likely to provide immunity against which of the following pathogens?
content_preview: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a routine well-child examination. She is given a vaccine that contains polyribosylribitol phosphate conjugated to a toxoid carrier. The vaccine is most likely to provide immunity against which of the following pathogens?
hint: A polyribosylribitol phosphate (PRP) capsule is an important virulence factor for certain strains of this pathogen.
learning_objective: Recall the target pathogen of the Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine.

answers.explanation_why: Streptococcus pneumoniae infections can be prevented with pneumococcal conjugate vaccines. Like the vaccine this patient received, pneumococcal vaccines are derived from purified capsular antigens. In order to elicit an immune response in infants and toddlers, the capsular antigens are conjugated to inactivated diphtheria toxin to stimulate T cells, which causes a more rapid and long-lasting immune response. However, the pneumococcal antigens are not polyribosylribitol phosphate, meaning it is not the vaccine in question. Pneumococcal vaccination is most often administered at 2 months of age.

Poliovirus can be prevented with the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV, Salk strain). A live attenuated vaccine (the Sabin vaccine) is also available. Unlike the vaccine mentioned here, there is no immunogenic polysaccharide fragment in polio vaccines. Because the live attenuated vaccine is associated with the rare adverse effect of vaccine-induced polio, the inactivated vaccine is recommended (it does not carry a risk of causing polio). The first dose of IPV is administered at 2 months of age.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, which can be prevented with a vaccine containing the inactivated diphtheria toxin. Because there are no clinically available vaccines against this organism that rely on a capsular protein, it is not the vaccine in question here. The vaccine is usually administered along with the tetanus and pertussis vaccine as the DTaP vaccine at 2 months of age.

Neisseria meningitidis virulence can be reduced by giving conjugate meningococcal vaccines to high-risk individuals. Capsular polysaccharides from the four most common virulent strains of N. meningitidis are typically conjugated to a diphtheria toxoid protein for enhanced immunogenicity. Unlike the vaccine mentioned here, the antigens are not polyribosylribitol phosphate. Furthermore, meningococcal vaccination is not routinely recommended at such an early age.

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) produces a polyribosylribitol phosphate capsule. This organism causes invasive diseases such as meningitis, epiglottitis, and septic arthritis, especially in early childhood. The PRP capsule is a strong virulence factor and plays a key role in the organism's pathogenicity by protecting it from complement-mediated lysis and phagocytosis. Vaccination is extremely effective at preventing these infections. Unencapsulated, nontypeable H. influenzae is not covered by the Hib vaccine; it is part of the normal nasopharyngeal flora and can cause otitis media, sinusitis, and conjunctivitis in children who have received the Hib vaccine.

The Haemophilus  influenzae type b vaccine contains the capsular polysaccharide conjugated to an immunogenic protein, such as diphtheria toxoid (conjugate vaccine). The Hib vaccine is generally administered at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth.

Bordetella pertussis infection can be prevented with the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine. The aP vaccine contains the inactivated pertussis toxin rather than polyribosylribitol phosphate capsular proteins. The host immune system produces protective antibodies against the toxin, reducing the odds of developing an infection in cases of exposure to B. pertussis. The first dose of aP is administered at 2 months.

question_text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years during her twenties. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m^2. Her pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum lipid studies and glucose concentration are within the reference ranges. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years during her twenties. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum lipid studies and glucose concentration are within the reference ranges. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This screening test is recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) for asymptomatic individuals ≥ 45 years of age.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for colorectal cancer screening in asymptomatic adults.

answers.explanation_why: The USPSTF recommends screening women ≥ 65 years of age for osteoporosis using bone measurement testing (e.g., DEXA scan or quantitative ultrasonography). Women < 65 years of age should be screened if they have a moderately increased risk for osteoporosis according to clinical tools, such as the Fracture Risk Assessment Tool. This patient does not have significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., personal or parental history of hip fracture, chronic glucocorticoid use, significant alcohol consumption, current smoking).

The USPSTF recommends screening all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age for colorectal cancer (the previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years). Screening strategies include annual fecal immunochemical testing, flexible sigmoidoscopy or CT colonography every 5 years, and colonoscopy screening every 10 years. Over 90% of cases of colorectal cancer occur in adults ≥ 45 years of age, and there is significant evidence that early detection decreases mortality.

Individuals with a first-degree relative with colorectal cancer or advanced adenoma diagnosed at < 60 years of age should start screening with complete colonoscopy at age 40 or 10 years earlier than the index patient's age at diagnosis; whichever is earlier.

The USPSTF has concluded that routine ECG screenings do not decrease the risk of myocardial infarction or stroke. Current evidence regarding routine ECG screening for atrial fibrillation is also insufficient to recommend this test.

The USPSTF has concluded that there is insufficient evidence to support routine thyroid function screening in nonpregnant patients. Pregnancy (particularly during the first trimester) can interfere with normal circulating levels of TSH. Women who are planning pregnancy and are at increased risk for thyroid disorders (e.g., family history of autoimmune thyroid disease, presence of a goiter) can be screened, but universal screening is not generally recommended.

The USPSTF recommends genetic counseling and potential genetic testing for BRCA mutations for women who have a positive result on a familial risk assessment tool that assesses risk for BRCA-related cancers (e.g., breast, ovarian, tubal, and peritoneal cancer). This patient has no such family history.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening with abdominal ultrasonography can be considered in individuals < 65 years of age who have multiple risk factors for AAA or a family history of AAA, neither of which applies to this patient.

question_text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for preconception counseling. She reports that she has been trying to conceive with her husband for 2 months. She has been in a monogamous relationship for 10 years. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She did not receive the MMR vaccine when she was young because of an “egg allergy.” Her vaccinations are otherwise up-to-date. Her only medication is a daily folic acid supplement. She feels well today. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. Her serum human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 3 mIU/mL (N ≤ 5). An HIV antibody/antigen test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for preconception counseling. She reports that she has been trying to conceive with her husband for 2 months. She has been in a monogamous relationship for 10 years. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She did not receive the MMR vaccine when she was young because of an “egg allergy.” Her vaccinations are otherwise up-to-date. Her only medication is a daily folic acid supplement. She feels well today. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. Her serum human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 3 mIU/mL (N ≤ 5). An HIV antibody/antigen test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has a normal serum β-hCG concentration, which indicates that she is not currently pregnant. Many diseases increase the risk to the fetus and birthing parent. However, certain diseases can be devastating to the fetus and are ideally addressed prior to conception.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for preconception care, and choose the appropriate screening test for immunity status.

answers.explanation_why: Iron supplementation (30–60 mg/day) is indicated in maternal iron deficiency anemia. Iron deficiency anemia can increase the risk of placental insufficiency and is the most common type of anemia in pregnancy. Iron supplementation is not needed if anemia is not present; this patient's complete blood count is within range.

As part of comprehensive preconception care, physicians should assess individuals' immunization status and recommend all routine age-appropriate immunizations. Because of the risk of congenital abnormalities following infection with rubella or varicella in pregnancy, the MMR and varicella vaccines are especially recommended. In patients with no evidence of immunity to rubella (e.g., those who did not receive the MMR vaccine), rubella antibody testing should be used to screen for immunity, and vaccination should be recommended in individuals without immunity. The MMR and varicella vaccines are live vaccines, which are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential risk of infection in the birthing parent and consequent vertical transmission. Accordingly, conception should be avoided for 1–3 months after immunization.

In the past, administering the MMR vaccine to children with egg allergies raised concerns because of residual egg proteins in the vaccine. However, the MMR vaccine is currently considered safe for children with egg allergy.

answers.content: Obtain rectal swab for group B streptococcus
answers.explanation_why: Group B streptococcus (GBS) infection can cause chorioamnionitis, neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia; vaginal and rectal swab for gram stain and culture can detect GBS. However, GBS screening is indicated at 36 0/7– 37 6/7 weeks of gestation rather than before conception.

Screening for chlamydia infection is recommended in all sexually active women < 25 years of age and all women who are at increased risk for a sexually transmitted infection (e.g., having more than one sex partner, using condoms inconsistently outside a mutually monogamous relationship, performing sex in exchange for money). This patient does not have any risk factors for chlamydia infection, so she does not need to be screened for it. All pregnant women should be screened for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, and syphilis at the initial examination (∼ 10 weeks gestation).

Patients who have overweight (BMI 25–29.9 kg/m^2) or obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m^2) are at higher risk of difficulty with conception and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Women with obesity are at higher risk for hypertension, diabetes, gestational diabetes, stillbirth, and babies that are large for gestational age. This patient's BMI of 22 is normal (18.5–24.9 kg/m^2), so she is not at increased risk for weight-related pregnancy complications.

A 1-hour oral glucose challenge test is used to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus. Potential complications of pregestational diabetes mellitus include gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, eclampsia, urinary tract infections, and fetal diabetic fetopathy. A 1-hour glucose challenge is indicated at 24–28 weeks of gestation; this patient's normal serum β-hCG concentration indicates that she is currently not pregnant. A hemoglobin A1C test would be used to detect pregestational diabetes mellitus.

hint: This patient is a healthy 26-year-old man who recently immigrated from the Philippines and wants to establish care. What screening test is appropriate for a healthy man from the Western Pacific region?
learning_objective: Recognize the need for hepatitis B screening in individuals from high-prevalence areas, and choose the most appropriate screening test.

answers.explanation_why:
Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections are common worldwide, with a global prevalence of approx. 250 million HBV carriers. Screening tests for HBV infection are indicated for asymptomatic patients who have a high risk for previous HBV exposure. This population includes people who were born in countries with high HBV prevalence, such as the Philippines (and all countries in Asia). Accordingly, this patient should undergo serologic testing for HBV, which includes the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody (anti-HBs).

Other populations that should receive screening for HBV infection include women who are pregnant, patients who receive immunosuppressive therapy, blood donors, and children with mothers who have HBV infection.

Testicular examination can be used to evaluate for masses that are concerning for testicular cancer, the most common solid malignant tumor in young men. However, because of the overall low incidence of testicular cancer and its high survival rate (5-year survival rate of > 95%), screening examinations (by either clinicians or patients) are unlikely to provide meaningful health benefits and are, therefore, not recommended in patients who are asymptomatic.

answers.content: Nucleic acid amplification tests for chlamydia and gonorrhea
answers.explanation_why: Routine screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea is not generally recommended for asymptomatic men without high-risk sexual behavior. Routine screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea is recommended for sexually active women < 25 years of age, women ≥ 25 years of age with a high risk of infection, and pregnant patients.

The hemoglobin A_1c concentration is a screening test for diabetes mellitus. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening individuals 35–70 years of age with a BMI ≥ 25 kg/m^2. The American Diabetes Association recommends screening all individuals ≥ 35 years, and individuals < 35 years of age with a BMI ≥ 25 kg/m^2 and at least one additional risk factor (e.g., physical inactivity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, a first-degree relative with diabetes). This 26-year-old patient has a BMI of 22 kg/m^2; screening for diabetes mellitus is not recommended for him at this time.

Pulmonary function tests such as spirometry are used to diagnose ventilatory disorders (e.g., obstructive lung diseases, restrictive lung diseases) but are not recommended as screening tests for lung disease in patients who are asymptomatic.

question_text: Four-month-old twins are brought to the physician for a well-child examination. They were born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and have been healthy since. The birth weight of the first infant was 2606 g (6 lb 3 oz); his current weight is 6600 g (14 lb 9 oz) and he is at the 30^th percentile. The birth weight of the second infant was 2580 g (5 lb 11 oz); her current weight is 6500 g (14 lb 5 oz) and she is at the 25^th percentile. Both of the twins can raise their head and chest in the prone position, reach for objects, localize sounds, and smile at sounds and sights. Two weeks ago, the female twin started propping herself up on her hands when prone. The mother expresses concern because the other twin is still unable to do so. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: Four-month-old twins are brought to the physician for a well-child examination. They were born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and have been healthy since. The birth weight of the first infant was 2606 g (6 lb 3 oz); his current weight is 6600 g (14 lb 9 oz) and he is at the 30th percentile. The birth weight of the second infant was 2580 g (5 lb 11 oz); her current weight is 6500 g (14 lb 5 oz) and she is at the 25th percentile. Both of the twins can raise their head and chest in the prone position, reach for objects, localize sounds, and smile at sounds and sights. Two weeks ago, the female twin started propping herself up on her hands when prone. The mother expresses concern because the other twin is still unable to do so. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: Twins, like all other children, develop at different speeds, and each twin should be evaluated separately for any delays in obtaining milestones.
learning_objective: Recognize that developmental milestones can vary between twins and reassure accordingly.

answers.content: "There is no reason for concern, but I will order blood tests to rule out a genetic disorder."
answers.explanation_why: Further evaluation including reviewing the newborn screening test and assessing for a genetic disorder would be warranted if the twin who cannot yet prop himself up failed to obtain the milestone by the time of his next well-child examination. At this time, there is no reason to pursue further testing.

answers.content: "I will refer you to a developmental pediatrician for further assessment."
answers.explanation_why: Further evaluation including a referral to a developmental pediatrician would be warranted if the twin who cannot yet prop himself up failed to obtain the milestone by the time of his next well-child examination. At this time, there is no reason for a referral.

answers.content: "We will set up examinations at shorter intervals until both children have achieved the same milestones."
answers.explanation_why: The twin who is unable to prop himself up will need to be reassessed at his next well-child examination, but there is no need to set up examinations at shorter intervals. Frequent examinations are only required for infants with certain risk factors (e.g., perinatal complications, genetic disorders, history of living in impoverished conditions, and/or domestic violence in the family), which are not present here.

answers.content: "I will order a detailed neurological assessment to further investigate your child's developmental delay."
answers.explanation_why: The twin who is unable to prop himself up would need a detailed neurological assessment only if he has red flags (e.g., hypertonia/hypotonia, dysmorphism, failure to thrive, positive newborn screening). Since he does not have any such red flags a detailed neurological assessment is not indicated at this time; he only needs to be reassessed at his next well-child examination. If he has failed to obtain the milestone by then, a detailed neurological examination will be performed.

answers.content: "There is no need to worry because differences between twins reaching milestones are normal."
answers.explanation_why: Developmental milestones are based on the mean age at which children can perform a particular task. Individual differences in the age at which some developmental milestones are achieved are normal. The mean age at which infants attain the ability to prop themselves up with their hands while prone is 6 months. Therefore, the mother of these 4-month-old twins should be reassured, while the children should be reevaluated during the next well-child visit at 6 months of age. A developmental delay should be suspected if a particular milestone does not occur by the expected age.

question_text:
A 24-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination in winter. He was last seen by the physician 12 months ago. His childhood vaccinations are up-to-date, but there is no documentation of human papillomavirus vaccination. He has no planned travel. Prior to starting college, he was appropriately vaccinated prior to living in residential dormitory housing. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

Influenza vaccination
Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination
Meningococcal ACWY vaccination
Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccination

A
Yes
yes
yes
no

B
Yes
no
yes
no

C
Yes
yes
no
no

D
No
no
no
yes

E
No
yes
no
yes

F
Yes
yes
yes
yes
content_preview: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination in winter. He was last seen by the physician 12 months ago. His childhood vaccinations are up-to-date, but there is no documentation of human papillomavirus vaccination. He has no planned travel. Prior to starting college, he was appropriately vaccinated prior to living in residential dormitory housing. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time? Influenza vaccination Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination Meningococcal ACWY vaccination Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccination A Yes yes yes no B Yes no yes no C Yes yes no no D No no no yes E No yes no yes F Yes yes yes yes
hint: This patient was appropriately vaccinated with the meningococcal vaccine prior to living in residential dormitory housing.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate vaccinations for a young healthy adult.

answers.explanation_why: The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and is not considered at high risk for infection with Neisseria meningitidis at this time.

The HPV vaccine is recommended for unvaccinated persons 11–26 years of age. This patient should be offered the HPV vaccine because he does not have any documentation of having received it.

The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and is not considered at high risk for infection with Neisseria meningitidis at this time.

All individuals ≥ 6 months of age should receive an influenza vaccine every flu season. In the northern hemisphere, the flu season runs Oct–April, so this patient should be offered the influenza vaccine. Contraindications include a history of anaphylaxis to any part of the vaccine, which this patient does not have.

The HPV vaccine is recommended for all unvaccinated persons 11–26 years of age. This patient should be offered the HPV vaccine because he does not have any documentation of having received it.

The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations, so he has already completed two routine doses of the meningococcal ACWY vaccine. Additional doses of the meningococcal vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., military recruits, first-year college students who reside in residential dormitory housing if not already vaccinated at ≥ 16 years of age; individuals with asplenia, HIV infection, complement inhibitor use, or a history of travel to high-risk countries). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

All individuals ≥ 6 months of age should receive an influenza vaccine every flu season. In the northern hemisphere, the flu season runs Oct–April, so this patient should be offered the influenza vaccine. Contraindications include a history of anaphylaxis to any part of the vaccine, which this patient does not have.

The HPV vaccine is recommended for unvaccinated persons 11–26 years of age. This patient should be offered the HPV vaccine because he does not have any documentation of having received it.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

All individuals ≥ 6 months of age should receive an influenza vaccine every flu season. In the northern hemisphere, the flu season runs Oct–April, so this patient should be offered the influenza vaccine. Contraindications include a history of anaphylaxis to any part of the vaccine, which this patient does not have.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations, so he has already completed two routine doses of the meningococcal ACWY vaccine. Additional doses of the meningococcal vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., military recruits, first-year college students who reside in residential dormitory housing if not already vaccinated at ≥ 16 years of age; individuals with asplenia, HIV infection, complement inhibitor use, or a history of travel to high-risk countries). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his parents are concerned about their son's physical changes. The parents say that he is showing signs of puberty earlier than his older siblings. He is about to turn 10 years in 2 months. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 97^th percentile for height and 99^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows Tanner stage 2 for pubic hair development and Tanner stage 3 for genital development. There is sparse, soft axillary hair. Which of the following actions by the physician is most appropriate?
content_preview: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his parents are concerned about their son's physical changes. The parents say that he is showing signs of puberty earlier than his older siblings. He is about to turn 10 years in 2 months. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 99th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows Tanner stage 2 for pubic hair development and Tanner stage 3 for genital development. There is sparse, soft axillary hair. Which of the following actions by the physician is most appropriate?
hint: The normal age of onset of puberty is 9–14 years in boys and 8–12 years in girls.
learning_objective: Recognize normal pubertal development, and choose the appropriate reassurance for age-related physical changes.

answers.explanation_why:
Reassurance is the best next step in management, as this 9-year-old boy's physical examination shows typical signs of the onset of puberty. Children do not start puberty at the same age, and, while he is developing earlier than his siblings, he is still within the normal distribution. Additionally, this patient is following the normal sequence of development (in boys: adrenarche, gonadarche, pubarche, and growth spurt) with Tanner stage 3 for genital development and Tanner stage 2 for pubic hair development. His height is in the 97^th percentile and weight is in the 99^th percentile, indicating that he has hit the pubertal growth spurt.

Precocious puberty should be suspected if secondary sex characteristics (e.g., testicular enlargement in males) appear before the age of 9 years in boys or 8 years in girls.

An MRI of the brain should be performed as part of the workup in patients with suspected central precocious puberty (CPP), as central nervous system (CNS) lesions are a common cause of CPP. Hamartomas in the hypothalamus are the most common type of CNS lesion associated with CPP in very young children; however, other symptoms, such as seizures, would be expected. Additionally, while this patient's physical changes started earlier than in his older siblings, he is within the normal age of onset of puberty for boys.

Serum testosterone levels should be measured in patients with suspected peripheral precocious puberty to further evaluate the underlying cause. Patients with excess testosterone production may present with precocious puberty. However, even though this patient is experiencing physical changes of puberty earlier than his older siblings, he is within the normal age of onset for boys. Therefore, there is no indication for measuring serum testosterone levels.

The GnRH stimulation test is used to differentiate between central and peripheral precocious puberty in cases in which LH is decreased or equivocal. However, while this 9-year-old boy is experiencing the physical changes of puberty earlier than his older siblings, he is within the normal age of onset of puberty for boys. Therefore, a GnRH stimulation test is not needed.

Ultrasound of the testicles can be used to evaluate patients with symptoms concerning for a testicular tumor. While Leydig cell tumors may manifest with precocious puberty due to testosterone production by the tumor, this patient's physical changes are taking place at the normal age of onset for puberty. Additionally, Leydig cell tumors often manifest with unilateral testicular enlargement, while this patient does not have asymmetrical genital development.

The measurement of serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels is usually performed in children when there is a suspicion of nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). However, nonclassic CAH is associated with precocious pubarche with delayed testicular enlargement, which is due to the adrenal source of precocity. This patient's pubic hair and genitals are developing in accordance with the normal sequence; he is at Tanner stage 2 for pubic hair development and Tanner stage 3 for genital development. Moreover, at 9 years old, this patient's changes would not be considered precocious, making nonclassic CAH unlikely.

Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her parents are concerned about their daughter's growth spurt. The parents say that she is showing signs of puberty earlier than her older siblings. She is about to turn 9 years old in 1 month. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medication. She is at the 96th percentile for height and 98th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows Tanner stage 1 for pubic hair development and Tanner stage 2 for genital development. There is sparse, soft axillary hair. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: The normal sequence of pubertal development is adrenarche → gonadarche → thelarche → growth spurt → pubarche → menarche.
learning_objective: Recall the normal range and sequence for the onset of puberty.

answers.explanation_why: CNS lesions, especially hamartomas in the hypothalamus, are a common cause of central precocious puberty in young children. This patient, however, is within the normal age range (8–12 years) for the onset of puberty and her physical changes follow the normal sequence of pubic hair and genital development. Furthermore, other signs of an intracranial tumor (e.g., headaches, seizures, focal neurological deficits) are absent.

Triple X syndrome (47, XXX), which develops due to chromosomal nondisjunction, can manifest with precocious puberty and tall stature in an otherwise healthy female adolescent. This patient, however, does not have precocious puberty. She is within the normal age range (8–12 years of age) for the onset of puberty, her physical changes follow the normal sequence of development with Tanner stage 1 for pubic hair and Tanner stage 2 for genital development, and her height is consistent with a normal pubertal growth spurt.

This patient shows typical signs of puberty. While she is entering puberty earlier than her other siblings, she is still within the normal range for the onset of puberty (8–12 years of age), for which variation in onset is not uncommon. In addition, this patient is following the normal sequence of development, with Tanner stage 1 for pubic hair and Tanner stage 2 for genital development. Her height is in the 96^th percentile and her weight is in the 98^th percentile, indicating that she has entered the pubertal growth spurt.

If secondary sex characteristics (e.g., breast development in girls, testicular enlargement in boys) appear before the age of 8 in girls or 9 in boys, precocious puberty should be suspected.

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which is typically due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, can manifest with precocious puberty in an otherwise asymptomatic female adolescent. This patient, however, is within the normal age range (8–12 years) for the onset of puberty and her physical changes follow the normal sequence of development with Tanner stage 1 for pubic hair and Tanner stage 2 for genital development.

Granulosa cell tumors can manifest with precocious puberty in an otherwise asymptomatic female adolescent. This patient, however, is entering puberty within the normal age range (8–12 years of age) for the onset of puberty and her physical changes follow the normal sequence of development with Tanner stage 1 for pubic hair and Tanner stage 2 for genital development.

question_text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child visit. The parents report that she has been crying excessively since the last visit and are concerned that she is not well. Their babysitter has told them that she does not stop crying even with feeding or burping. They say that she used to be calm when she was left alone, but over the past week, she starts to cry whenever they leave the room. She was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age. Her parents have gradually introduced semisolid foods over the past three months. She is at the 75^th percentile for height and weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she turns her head when her name is called. She coos “ma” and “da.” She crawls on the examination table, is able to independently get into a seated position, and passes a teddy from one hand to the other. She can be pulled up to stand but cannot stand without support. Plantar reflex is present bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is soft. She begins to cry when the physician picks her up. The remainder of the examination does not show any abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child visit. The parents report that she has been crying excessively since the last visit and are concerned that she is not well. Their babysitter has told them that she does not stop crying even with feeding or burping. They say that she used to be calm when she was left alone, but over the past week, she starts to cry whenever they leave the room. She was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age. Her parents have gradually introduced semisolid foods over the past three months. She is at the 75th percentile for height and weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she turns her head when her name is called. She coos “ma” and “da.” She crawls on the examination table, is able to independently get into a seated position, and passes a teddy from one hand to the other. She can be pulled up to stand but cannot stand without support. Plantar reflex is present bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is soft. She begins to cry when the physician picks her up. The remainder of the examination does not show any abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This 9-month old child presents with the appropriate gross motor skills (able to independently get into a seated position), fine motor skills (transfers objects from one hand to the other), and language milestones (cooing “ma” and “da”) for her age. Plantar reflex usually disappears around 12 months of age.
learning_objective: Recognize normal behavior in a 9-month-old child.

answers.explanation_why: Separation anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety of separation from major attachment figures such as the parents and usually develops during childhood. Although this infant presents with symptoms of separation anxiety (e.g., starts to cry when her parents leave the room), the diagnosis of separation anxiety disorder cannot be established at this age.

Reactive attachment disorder manifests with an inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior towards caretakers without seeking comfort when distressed. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures, which is not consistent with reactive attachment disorder.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) usually manifests with detachment and inability or difficulty to form relationships. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures. Moreover, patients with ASD typically present with other findings such as abnormal language development and stereotypical patterns of behavior (e.g., hand flapping, adverse response to sounds), none of which is seen here.

Infantile colic manifests with episodes of crying in otherwise healthy and thriving infants, which is seen here. However, crying in infantile colic is not associated with the absence of attachment figures, or the presence of strangers. Moreover, infantile colic typically resolves spontaneously by 3–4 months of age.

This 9-month-old child presents with milestones that are appropriate for her age. Her crying pattern is consistent with stranger anxiety (crying when picked up by strangers) and separation anxiety (crying when her parents leave the room), both of which are typical and normal social behaviors in children of this age. See “Developmental milestones in infants” table.

This infant shows no signs or symptoms suggestive of physical child abuse (e.g., injuries at different stages of healing). Infants who are subject to sexual child abuse may present with normal physical examination findings or with findings restricted to genital and anal areas, which can easily be overseen. Sexual child abuse should be considered in children with recurrent urinary tract infections and behavioral changes. This patient's presentation, however, is not suggestive of sexual child abuse or other types of child abuse (e.g., child neglect).

question_text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a scheduled immunization visit. The patient's father reports that the patient had continual crying, increased irritability, and fever for the past 2 days. He has noticed that the patient keeps tugging at his left ear. The patient was born at 32 weeks' gestation but has been otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. At the fourth well-child visit, the third dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis B (HepB) vaccines were administered. He is at the 25^th percentile for length and weight with respect to chronological age; when corrected for gestational age, he is at the 40^th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F); the remainder of his vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane; examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Treatment with ibuprofen and amoxicillin is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician regarding immunization?
content_preview: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a scheduled immunization visit. The patient's father reports that the patient had continual crying, increased irritability, and fever for the past 2 days. He has noticed that the patient keeps tugging at his left ear. The patient was born at 32 weeks' gestation but has been otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. At the fourth well-child visit, the third dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis B (HepB) vaccines were administered. He is at the 25th percentile for length and weight with respect to chronological age; when corrected for gestational age, he is at the 40th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F); the remainder of his vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane; examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Treatment with ibuprofen and amoxicillin is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician regarding immunization?
hint: If there are no absolute contraindications, immunizations indicated at 12 months include the fourth Hib dose; fourth PCV15 dose; first measles, mumps, and rubella dose; and first varicella dose.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate immunization recommendation for a child with mild acute illness.

answers.content: Administer standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit
answers.explanation_why:
This patient should receive the standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit. Neither mild acute illness (e.g., upper respiratory tract infection, otitis media, low-grade fever, mild diarrhea) nor current antibiotic therapy are contraindications for vaccination (except for oral live typhoid vaccine, because antibiotics might compromise the immune response to this vaccine). All children must be immunized with the standard doses of vaccines according to their chronological age; doses should not be adjusted to weight or gestational age.

The only vaccine that depends on the child's birth weight is the first dose of HepB vaccine; infants with a birth weight < 2 kg should receive the first dose of the vaccine at 1 month of age or at hospital discharge, whichever occurs first.

answers.content: Administer weight-adjusted doses of all due vaccines after the illness resolves
answers.explanation_why: Valid contraindications for vaccination include previous severe allergic reactions related to vaccination (e.g., anaphylaxis) and severe allergies to components of a vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness with or without fever is a precaution for vaccine administration. Mild illnesses, such as otitis media and low-grade fever are not contraindications for vaccination. Adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

answers.content: Administer standard doses of all due vaccines after 5 weeks
answers.explanation_why: Preterm infants should be vaccinated at the same chronological age, according to the same schedule, and using the same precautions as full-term infants. Correction for gestational age is not recommended.

answers.content: Administer weight-adjusted doses of all vaccines due at this visit
answers.explanation_why: Vaccination is contraindicated in patients who have experienced a severe allergic reaction to a prior dose or component of a vaccine, which is not seen here. However, adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

answers.content: Administer standard doses of inactivated vaccines at this visit and live vaccines after the illness resolves
answers.explanation_why: Live attenuated vaccines are not recommended in pregnant and/or immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those receiving immunosuppressive therapy, patients with congenital immunodeficiencies, severely immunocompromised patients with HIV). In such cases, the standard doses of inactivated vaccines might be indicated, but the administration of live vaccines should be postponed until after delivery or until the patient is no longer considered immunocompromised. This patient has neither of these contraindications, so another approach would be more appropriate.

question_text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her mother died of lung cancer at the age of 55 years. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with a female partner. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years. She does not drink alcoholic beverages or use illicit drugs. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following conditions is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her mother died of lung cancer at the age of 55 years. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with a female partner. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years. She does not drink alcoholic beverages or use illicit drugs. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following conditions is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Most adults only need to be screened for this condition once.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate condition for routine health screening in adults.

answers.explanation_why: Asymptomatic bacteriuria screening with urine culture is recommended for all pregnant persons during the first trimester. Screening is not otherwise recommended for healthy, nonpregnant individuals.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) screening (e.g., with complete colonoscopy or a fecal occult blood test) is recommended for adults ≥ 45 years of age. Individuals with a history of CRC or adenomatous polyps, a first-degree relative with CRC, or a hereditary syndrome associated with increased risk of CRC (e.g., familial adenomatous polyposis) are at increased risk and should receive more frequent screening. This 37-year-old patient has no identified risk factors for CRC and, therefore, does not require screening for this condition at this time.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening with abdominal ultrasonography can be considered in individuals < 65 years of age who have multiple risk factors or a positive family history for AAA, neither of which applies to this patient.

All individuals ≥ 18 years of age should be screened for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection at least once in their lifetime. More frequent screening is recommended for individuals with risk factors for HCV infection, such as a history of injection drug use, solid-organ transplantation, long-term hemodialysis, or HIV infection. Screening is performed by testing the serum for anti-HCV antibodies; if screening is positive, the diagnosis can be confirmed with polymerase chain reaction testing for HCV RNA. With direct-acting antiviral treatment, the rate of complete cure with sustained virological response is over > 90%.

Atrial fibrillation screening (e.g., with ECG) is not recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force because of a lack of evidence assessing the benefits and potential harm related to screening. The American Heart Association and the American Stroke Association recommend screening in adults > 65 years of age. This 37-year-old patient does not require screening for atrial fibrillation at this time.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease screening is not recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force, as early detection does not change the course of the disease or improve patient outcomes.

question_text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
hint: Screening for this disorder is recommended by the American Heart Association and various other expert groups for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate screening for a middle-aged adult male with no additional ASCVD risk factors.

answers.explanation_why:
Early detection and treatment of hyperlipidemia is crucial to prevent ASCVD events like stroke or myocardial infarction. The guidelines for hyperlipidemia screening differ slightly among various expert groups. The current consensus is to screen all individuals aged 20–75 years using a fasting or nonfasting serum lipid profile test every 4–6 years in patients without additional ASCVD risk factors and at more frequent intervals in those with additional ASCVD risk factors. 

See “Screening recommendations for men by age” table.

Chlamydia and gonorrhea are the most common causes of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID is most often asymptomatic, it can result in severe complications, including infertility and ectopic pregnancy. Therefore, both the USPSTF and CDC recommend annual screening with a nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active women < 25 years and women ≥ 25 years with certain risk factors (e.g., new or multiple sex partners, a sex partner with an STI). The CDC also recommends annual screening for both sexually active HIV-positive men and men who have sex with men because of the higher incidence of gonorrhea and chlamydia infections in these populations. Routine chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is not currently recommended for sexually active, HIV-negative men in monogamous, heterosexual relationships, such as this patient.
The AHA and other expert groups do recommend screening for a certain disease in this patient's age group.

The guidelines for prostate cancer screening differ slightly among various expert groups but the USPSTF recommends screening men aged 55–69 years with a life expectancy of at least 10 years after informing the patient of the benefits as well as risks of prostate cancer screening (e.g., relatively high false-positive rate, additional unnecessary procedures), i.e., by employing a shared decision-making strategy. Prostate cancer screening is most commonly performed using a serum prostate-specific antigen test every 2 years. Screening can be initiated earlier at 40 years for patients with a first-degree relative who developed early-onset prostate cancer (i.e., before 65 years). This 42-year-old patient with a second-degree relative who developed prostate cancer at the age of 73 years does not require prostate cancer screening at this visit.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend routine screening for osteoporosis in men, but screening can be considered in men with strong risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use; androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer) and in men ≥ 70 years of age. In this 42-year old man without such risk factors, screening for osteoporosis is not recommended.

question_text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born by cesarean delivery at 36 weeks’ gestation because of bleeding due to placenta previa. There is no family history of serious illness. She can prop herself up on her hands when in a prone position and rolls from front to back. When placed in a seated position, she leans on her hands to support herself. She can grasp her toy rattle with her index finger and thumb and can transfer it from one hand to the other. She babbles “mama” and “dada.” She cries if anyone apart from her parents holds her or plays with her. She laughs when her parents play peek-a-boo and orients to her name. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is at the 55^th percentile for head circumference, 40^th percentile for length, and 45^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following developmental milestones is delayed in this infant?
content_preview: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born by cesarean delivery at 36 weeks’ gestation because of bleeding due to placenta previa. There is no family history of serious illness. She can prop herself up on her hands when in a prone position and rolls from front to back. When placed in a seated position, she leans on her hands to support herself. She can grasp her toy rattle with her index finger and thumb and can transfer it from one hand to the other. She babbles “mama” and “dada.” She cries if anyone apart from her parents holds her or plays with her. She laughs when her parents play peek-a-boo and orients to her name. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is at the 55th percentile for head circumference, 40th percentile for length, and 45th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following developmental milestones is delayed in this infant?
learning_objective: Recognize delayed gross motor development in infants.

answers.explanation_why: This patient orients to her name, which is an example of appropriate cognitive development in a 9-month-old child.

This patient transfers objects from one hand to the other and uses the pincer grasp (pinches objects between the tips of the index finger and the thumb). These abilities are examples of appropriate fine motor skill development in a 9-month-old child.

By the age of 9 months, a child should be able to independently get into a seated position and sit without support. This child is only able to prop herself up on her hands when in a prone position, roll from front to back, and sit in a tripod position when placed in a seated position, all of which reflect the gross motor skills of a 6-month-old child. See “Developmental milestones in infants” table.

The delay of a milestone, especially in combination with a problematic history, such as the complicated preterm birth of this patient, should prompt further evaluation. Since developmental milestones are not a precise tool for measuring pediatric development, the delay of a milestone should prompt further evaluation, e.g., using standardized developmental screening tests such as the Denver Developmental Screening Test II. If these tests confirm the presence of developmental delay, the underlying causes should be investigated and early intervention initiated.

This patient cries when someone unfamiliar holds her or plays with her, which are signs of stranger anxiety and separation anxiety. These behaviors are examples of appropriate social development in a 9-month-old child and are, therefore, not concerning at this time.
This patient babbles disyllabic words (“mama”, “dada”), which is an example of appropriate language development in a 9-month-old child.
