question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of intermittent breast tenderness. The patient says, “Some of the kids on my swimming team are making fun of me because it looks like I have breasts.” He has mild persistent asthma well controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. He appears anxious. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows firm, mobile, mildly tender bilateral masses located beneath the nipple-areolar complex; the mass on the right is 1 cm in diameter, the mass on the left is 0.6 cm in diameter. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 3. The remainder of the examination, including genitourinary examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of intermittent breast tenderness. The patient says, “Some of the kids on my swimming team are making fun of me because it looks like I have breasts.” He has mild persistent asthma well controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. He appears anxious. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Physical examination shows firm, mobile, mildly tender bilateral masses located beneath the nipple-areolar complex; the mass on the right is 1 cm in diameter, the mass on the left is 0.6 cm in diameter. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 3. The remainder of the examination, including genitourinary examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's condition is caused by an estrogen/androgen imbalance.
learning_objective: Recognize pubertal gynecomastia, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Core-needle biopsy is a minimally invasive tool used to diagnose suspicious breast masses seen on ultrasonography or mammography. This patient's firm, mobile, mildly tender breast masses are consistent with a benign process, for which a core-needle biopsy is not required.

Several drugs are associated with the development of gynecomastia, including ketoconazole, spironolactone, and H_2-receptor antagonists (e.g., cimetidine). However, this patient's only medication is albuterol, a short-acting beta-2 agonist that is not known to cause gynecomastia.

Karyotype analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome, which can manifest with bilateral gynecomastia in an adolescent. However, most patients with Klinefelter syndrome also present with additional signs of hypoandrogenism such as eunuchoid growth pattern, reduced facial and body hair, and testicular atrophy, none of which are seen here.

Serum TSH concentration is measured in patients with suspected hyperthyroidism, which can manifest with bilateral gynecomastia. However, individuals with hyperthyroidism typically present with weight loss, heat intolerance, cardiovascular features (e.g., tachycardia, palpitations), and a goiter, none of which is seen here.

Scrotal ultrasound can be used to diagnose sex-cord stromal tumors (e.g., Leydig cell tumors), which can manifest with bilateral gynecomastia. However, patients with these tumors typically present with precocious puberty in childhood. Additionally, a testicular tumor commonly manifests with a palpable testicular mass, whereas this patient's pelvic examination showed no abnormalities.

An MRI of the brain is indicated in patients with a suspected pituitary mass, which can manifest with signs of hypogonadism (e.g., gynecomastia). Although the secondary hypogonadism and bilateral gynecomastia observed in this adolescent boy could result from a pituitary adenoma, he lacks other features of the disease, such as delayed puberty, loss of facial and body hair, testicular atrophy, and signs of pituitary mass effect (e.g., headaches, bitemporal hemianopsia).

Puberty in boys usually begins at the age of 9–14 years and is associated with a variety of physiological changes, including testicular volume increase, penile enlargement, changes in the growth of pubic and axillary hair, voice deepening, and a growth spurt. Breast tissue enlargement is another physiological change that occurs during puberty and typically manifests with small, firm, mobile breast masses that are either unilateral or bilateral. Pubertal gynecomastia is due to a more rapid increase in estrogen levels compared to testosterone and generally resolves by the age of 17–18 years when the adult ratio of estrogen/androgen is reached. Since this patient does not present with any concerning symptoms (e.g., overlying skin changes, nipple discharge, rapid enlargement of either mass, excessive pain), reassurance and observation are sufficient. If gynecomastia persists after 17–18 years of age, surgical removal of the breast glandular tissue can be considered.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. He feels well. His last visit to the office was 6 years ago. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and carotid artery stenosis for which he takes metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. His father died from an ischemic stroke at the age of 74 years. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. He drinks two 12-oz beers weekly. Immunizations are up-to-date and a colonoscopy performed 8 years ago was unremarkable. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m^2. His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. He feels well. His last visit to the office was 6 years ago. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and carotid artery stenosis for which he takes metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. His father died from an ischemic stroke at the age of 74 years. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. He drinks two 12-oz beers weekly. Immunizations are up-to-date and a colonoscopy performed 8 years ago was unremarkable. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for this condition in men 65–75 years of age who are current or former smokers.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate screening for a 66-year-old former smoker.

answers.explanation_why: The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, no adenomatous polyps, no family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 8 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

This patient's hypertension, history of smoking, and advanced age increase the risk of developing an intracranial aneurysm. However, screening in asymptomatic patients is not indicated in the general population because it is not cost-effective, owing to the prevalence being too low and these aneurysms having a low risk of rupture. Screening may be considered in patients with genetic conditions associated with a higher incidence of intracranial aneurysms (e.g., autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) and in patients with first-degree relatives with a history of intracranial aneurysms, neither of which is seen here.

The USPSTF recommends annual screening with a low-dose CT scan of the chest in patients 50–80 years of age who have at least a 20 pack-year smoking history and who are current smokers or have stopped within the past 15 years. This patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history, but he stopped smoking 25 years ago. A low-dose CT scan of the chest is, therefore, not recommended at this time.

The USPSTF recommends that men 65–75 years of age who are current or former smokers should receive a one-time screening with ultrasonography for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Ultrasonography can determine the presence and size of an aneurysm, as well as the presence of a blood clot in an aneurysm. It is also the modality of choice for monitoring patients with small, asymptomatic AAAs.

The USPSTF recommends osteoporosis screening with bone densitometry scan every 10 years for women aged 65 years or older. Although some suggest a one-time screening for men older than 70 years of age, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that screening is beneficial in younger men. Therefore, screening for osteoporosis is not indicated in this patient.

question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the office to establish care after moving to the area from a different state with her husband and 3 children. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and constipation. Her current medication includes valsartan, salmeterol, and a fiber supplement for constipation. She entered menopause last year. Four years ago, she underwent hemorrhoidectomy; a sigmoidoscopy at that time showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 66 years; the patient's last mammogram from 6 months ago was normal. Her last primary HPV test taken 3 years ago was negative. She does not drink alcohol. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 8 years ago when she was diagnosed with COPD. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows varicose veins in the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable for her age. Which of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the office to establish care after moving to the area from a different state with her husband and 3 children. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and constipation. Her current medication includes valsartan, salmeterol, and a fiber supplement for constipation. She entered menopause last year. Four years ago, she underwent hemorrhoidectomy; a sigmoidoscopy at that time showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 66 years; the patient's last mammogram from 6 months ago was normal. Her last primary HPV test taken 3 years ago was negative. She does not drink alcohol. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 8 years ago when she was diagnosed with COPD. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows varicose veins in the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable for her age. Which of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?
hint: This screening study is recommended by the United States Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF) in adults aged 50 to 80 years.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate screening study for lung cancer in a former smoker with a significant smoking history.

answers.content: Low-dose CT scan of the chest
answers.explanation_why:
Annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is indicated for lung cancer screening in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a smoking history ≥ 20 pack years. Screening recommendations for former smokers vary. Although the American Cancer Society supports screening regardless of time since last smoked, some organizations (e.g., USPSTF) recommend limiting screening to individuals who have smoked within the past 15 years.

See “Screening for cancer” and “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” tables.

The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Sigmoidoscopy every 5 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last sigmoidoscopy 4 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), sigmoidoscopy is not indicated at this time.

Mammography is indicated for the screening of breast cancer in women aged 40–74 years. According to the latest 2024 USPSTF recommendation, mammography should be repeated every 2 years. This patient had a mammogram 6 months ago with normal findings and does not require any further testing right now.

According to the USPSTF recommendation, Pap smear is indicated for the screening of cervical cancer in women aged 21 to 65 years. Pap smear should be performed every 3 years if done alone, or every 5 years when performed as co-testing. Alternatively, in patients aged 30 to 65 years, the FDA-approved primary HPV tests performed every 5 years are sufficient for cervical cancer screening. This patient had HPV testing 3 years ago and does not require any further testing at this time.

Abdominal ultrasonography is used to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and is recommended in men 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history. Screening can also be considered in women 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history, in individuals < 65 years of age with multiple risk factors for AAA and/or a family history of AAA, and in individuals 65–75 years of age with a positive family history for AAA in a first-degree relative. Based on this patient's sex, age, and risk factors, screening for a different condition with another modality is indicated at this time.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. Two weeks ago, she gave birth to a healthy girl. Vaginal delivery was uncomplicated and mother and child were discharged after 3 days. Since the delivery of the child, the patient has had vaginal discharge that changed color from red to yellow. She has no pain with urination. She says that she has not been getting much sleep since her daughter's birth and often feels tired. She has not had depressed mood or excessive worrying. The child is exclusively breastfed. The patient has a history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. She used to take metformin that was switched to insulin during pregnancy. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband, two children, and the newborn in a small town in Wyoming. Her only sexual partner is her husband. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m^2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilaterally engorged, slightly tender breasts with erythematous nipples and a firm, nontender uterine fundus palpable at the height of the symphysis. There are yellowish stains on the perineal pad. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. Two weeks ago, she gave birth to a healthy girl. Vaginal delivery was uncomplicated and mother and child were discharged after 3 days. Since the delivery of the child, the patient has had vaginal discharge that changed color from red to yellow. She has no pain with urination. She says that she has not been getting much sleep since her daughter's birth and often feels tired. She has not had depressed mood or excessive worrying. The child is exclusively breastfed. The patient has a history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. She used to take metformin that was switched to insulin during pregnancy. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband, two children, and the newborn in a small town in Wyoming. Her only sexual partner is her husband. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilaterally engorged, slightly tender breasts with erythematous nipples and a firm, nontender uterine fundus palpable at the height of the symphysis. There are yellowish stains on the perineal pad. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is from Wyoming but the following step in management applies to all women of reproductive age in the US when they come to the office as a new patient.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management for a new patient of reproductive age.

answers.content: Offer referral to a weight loss program
answers.explanation_why: Referral to a weight loss program or other behavioral interventions is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for patients with a BMI of 30 kg/m^2 or higher to prevent obesity-related morbidity and mortality. This patient has a BMI of 27 kg/m^2.

Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are indicated to evaluate for thyroid disorders such as postpartum thyroiditis. Although postpartum thyroiditis can manifest with fatigue, other features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, palpitations, intolerance to heat) or hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, constipation) would be expected as well. Furthermore, postpartum thyroiditis is typically associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus, not type 2.

answers.content: Screen for emotional and physical partner violence
answers.explanation_why:
The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening all women of reproductive age for intimate partner violence (IPV). According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), in the US, a little under 50% of women and men experience IPV during their lifetime. The risk of IPV increases during pregnancy and the postpartum period. Screening can help to address immediate threats and prevent long-term IPV-associated conditions (e.g., posttraumatic stress disorder). To screen for IPV, the physician can ask a single nonjudgmental and nonstigmatizing question (e.g., “Some of the patients I see have been hurt or threatened by someone close to them. Is this something that you have experienced?”). IPV screening tools include the HARK questions, HITS screening tool, and STaT questions. Management of IPV includes immediate and, most importantly, ongoing support.

The USPSTF does not recommend routine screening for IPV in other patient groups (men, women not of reproductive age, vulnerable individuals, older adults) because of a lack of evidence that such interventions provide any benefit to these patients. Other sources do recommend screening for IPV in these patient groups because of an absence of harm and a potential benefit. The WHO recommends targeted screening for patients with red flags for IPV.

Urine culture is indicated in the diagnostic workup of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in select cases (e.g., uncomplicated lower UTI if urinalysis is negative but suspicion persists, complicated lower UTI, suspected upper UTI). This patient has no signs of UTI (e.g., dysuria, fever) and her vaginal discharge is most consistent with normal lochia. In patients with suspected sexually transmitted infection (e.g., patients with thick yellow, malodorous vaginal discharge), other tests would be indicated (e.g., nucleic acid amplification test, vaginal smear).

Behavioral counseling on sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for all sexually active adolescents and for adults at increased risk of STIs (e.g., who do not consistently use condoms and have several sexual partners). This patient is not part of either of these groups.

question_text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of irritability, drooling, and soft stools for the past 3 days. He has been sleeping poorly because he frequently wakes up crying, and breastfeeding does not always help to calm him. Yesterday, the mother noticed that he grabbed his right ear repeatedly and that he “felt a bit hotter than usual.” He is otherwise healthy and has been meeting all of his developmental milestones. He was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age, when solid foods were introduced to his diet. He usually has a bowel movement 1–3 times per day. He has had no difficulty voiding. His only medication is a vitamin D supplement. His immunizations are up to date. He is at the 40^th percentile for height and at the 45^th percentile for weight. He is alert and fully oriented. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a crying infant. He is drooling and calms when a plastic toy is put in his mouth. Otoscopic examination shows normal tympanic membranes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. His diaper contains soft yellow-brown stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of irritability, drooling, and soft stools for the past 3 days. He has been sleeping poorly because he frequently wakes up crying, and breastfeeding does not always help to calm him. Yesterday, the mother noticed that he grabbed his right ear repeatedly and that he “felt a bit hotter than usual.” He is otherwise healthy and has been meeting all of his developmental milestones. He was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age, when solid foods were introduced to his diet. He usually has a bowel movement 1–3 times per day. He has had no difficulty voiding. His only medication is a vitamin D supplement. His immunizations are up to date. He is at the 40th percentile for height and at the 45th percentile for weight. He is alert and fully oriented. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a crying infant. He is drooling and calms when a plastic toy is put in his mouth. Otoscopic examination shows normal tympanic membranes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. His diaper contains soft yellow-brown stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: The first eruption of teeth in babies typically occurs at 6–12 months of age and can be associated with irritability, subfebrile temperatures, drooling, ear pulling, and soft stools, the combination of which is sometimes referred to as teething syndrome.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate recommendation for teething syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Scheduled acetaminophen administration is indicated for infants with teething syndrome that cannot be managed with other methods. The treatment of teething is primarily palliative and nonpharmacologic methods should first be attempted before systemic analgesia is used.

answers.content: Give baby a chilled rubber ring
answers.explanation_why: Teething is best treated by allowing the baby to chew on a chilled (not frozen) teething device or applying pressure to the baby's gum using clean fingers or wet gauze. The teething device should be in one piece to prevent choking or injury to the mouth and should not be dipped in sugary substances to avoid causing dental caries. Systemic analgesics (e.g., acetaminophen, ibuprofen) are reserved for teething pain not effectively managed with conservative interventions.

Topic anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine, benzocaine) should be avoided in infants due to the high risk of intoxication and serious adverse reactions. For example, the use of benzocaine sprays or gels has been associated with inducing life-threatening methemoglobinemia in infants.

answers.content: Obtain complete blood count and stool culture
answers.explanation_why: Laboratory studies and stool cultures are indicated for infectious workup of diarrheal illness. This patient's symptoms are most likely the result of teething, and diarrhea can occur as a part of teething syndrome, so further workup is unnecessary in the absence of other signs of infection (i.e., normal abdominal examination, appropriate stool color, normal vital signs).

answers.content: Let baby chew on clean washcloth dipped in sugar-water
answers.explanation_why: Allowing babies to chew on a washcloth is appropriate for the treatment of teething syndrome, but dipping teething devices in sugary water should be avoided because this increases the risk of dental caries.

question_text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination after starting a new job as a marketing manager. She feels well. Her medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with ramipril, and prediabetes well-controlled with diet and exercise. She had asthma during childhood but has not required treatment since the age of 14 years. Last year, she had a kidney stone that passed spontaneously. Four years ago, she had a mammogram and a colonoscopy, which showed no abnormalities. She is sexually active with her husband only. She has no children. Menopause occurred at the age of 51 years. Her mother was diagnosed with renal cancer at the age of 69 years. She smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 12 years but quit 17 years ago. She drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (172 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m^2. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 131/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. At this time, screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination after starting a new job as a marketing manager. She feels well. Her medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with ramipril, and prediabetes well-controlled with diet and exercise. She had asthma during childhood but has not required treatment since the age of 14 years. Last year, she had a kidney stone that passed spontaneously. Four years ago, she had a mammogram and a colonoscopy, which showed no abnormalities. She is sexually active with her husband only. She has no children. Menopause occurred at the age of 51 years. Her mother was diagnosed with renal cancer at the age of 69 years. She smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 12 years but quit 17 years ago. She drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (172 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 131/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. At this time, screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The United States Preventive Services Taskforce (USPSTF) recommends screening for this type of cancer between 40 and 74 years of age.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate cancer screening for a 54-year-old woman.

answers.explanation_why: Annual lung cancer screening with a low-dose CT scan is recommended for individuals aged 50–80 years who have a smoking history of ≥ 20 pack-year. Although this patient is 54 years old and a former smoker, she only has a 12-pack-year smoking history, which makes her unsuitable for lung cancer screening at this time.

For women with an average risk of breast cancer, the USPSTF recommends mammography screening every 2 years starting no later than 40 years of age. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and American Cancer Society also recommend starting screening mammography at 40 years of age and advise clinicians to consider screening annually rather than biennially. Because this patient is 54 years of age, and her last mammogram was 4 years ago, she is due for breast cancer screening.

See “Cancer screening” table.

According to the USPSTF, colorectal cancer screening with colonoscopy is recommended for all average-risk individuals aged 45–75 years every 10 years. Since this patient has no known risk factors for colorectal cancer (e.g., family history of colorectal cancer or hereditary cancer syndromes, personal history of adenomatous polyps, colorectal cancer, or inflammatory bowel disease) and her last colonoscopy performed 4 years ago showed no abnormalities, she does not require colorectal cancer screening at this time.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) screening may be considered in patients who have a high risk of developing hereditary RCC (e.g., personal or family history of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome). Although this patient's mother had RCC, the timing of her diagnosis suggests a sporadic, rather than hereditary, case of RCC, and puts this patient in an average, rather than a high-risk group for RCC. There is no routine RCC screening currently recommended for average-risk individuals.

Pancreatic cancer screening may be considered in patients who have a high risk of developing hereditary pancreatic cancer (e.g., personal or family history of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome). Although this patient has a number of predisposing factors for pancreatic cancer (e.g., smoking history, overweight, prediabetes, alcohol consumption), she has no personal or family history of any hereditary cancer syndromes and is therefore in an average, rather than a high-risk group for pancreatic cancer. There is no routine pancreatic cancer screening currently recommended for average-risk individuals.

question_text: A 73-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. Following the recent death of his wife, he moved in with his daughter. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is physically active and exercises three to four times weekly. His medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (177 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymoses on the dorsal aspect of the patient's forearms bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 205,000/mm^3, a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time of 30 seconds, and a bleeding time of 3 minutes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical examination findings?
content_preview: A 73-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. Following the recent death of his wife, he moved in with his daughter. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is physically active and exercises three to four times weekly. His medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (177 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymoses on the dorsal aspect of the patient's forearms bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 205,000/mm3, a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time of 30 seconds, and a bleeding time of 3 minutes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical examination findings?
hint: Other findings associated with this patient's presentation include presbyopia, occasional word-finding difficulty, and bilateral hearing loss.
learning_objective: Recognize senile purpura as a normal aging process.

answers.explanation_why: Aspirin use increases the risk of bleeding, bleeding time, and bruising, which typically manifest as ecchymoses after minor trauma (most commonly on the lower extremities). While this patient has bilateral ecchymoses on the dorsal forearms, it was not preceded by any trauma. The absence of prior trauma and this patient's normal bleeding time make aspirin use an unlikely explanation for his symptoms.

Senile purpura is a benign skin condition that typically affects individuals aged > 50 years and manifests with recurrent, irregularly-shaped, dark purple macules. It is caused by progressive loss of dermal connective tissue, subcutaneous fat, and blood vessel elasticity with age, all of which results in increased susceptibility to bruising in elderly individuals. Senile purpura is more common in light-skinned persons (due to increased sensitivity to sunlight) and typically develops on sun-exposed areas (e.g., forearms, face, neck). The diagnosis is clinical and does not require further evaluation.

images.title: Senile purpura and skin atrophy
images.description: Forearm of an elderly patientThere are multiple irregular dark purple macules with well-defined margins. The surrounding skin appears thin and inelastic.

answers.explanation_why: Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) can develop in a patient aged > 55 years and manifest with ecchymoses. However, ITP is characterized by a low platelet count (< 100,000/mm^3). This patient's normal platelet count is inconsistent with ITP.

Nutrient deficiency (e.g., protein malnutrition, vitamin K or vitamin C deficiency) can increase an individual's risk of bleeding and bruising and manifest with ecchymoses. However, nutrient deficiency typically develops in individuals who are chronically ill, have limited access to food, or have malabsorption diseases (e.g., pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease), none of which apply to this man.

Physical abuse is a potential cause of bruising in an elderly individual with a normal coagulation profile. However, most elderly individuals who experience physical abuse present with asymmetric skin lesions in unusual locations, unexplained fractures, signs of malnutrition, depressed mood, and, in rare cases, suicidality. This patient's isolated bruising and the symmetric bilateral ecchymoses on the dorsal forearms make another etiology more likely.

question_text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy since. There is no family history of serious illness. She can write her own name, is able to tie a knot, and can hop on one foot. Her father says that she has started watching television and often plays with his cell phone. She attends school regularly. She has been at the 50^th percentile for both height and weight for the last 2 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The father is concerned about the effects of media exposure on his child. The physician recommends limiting screen time to approximately 1 hour daily, content monitoring by parents, and the use of a family media plan with child safety filters. At this visit, it is most appropriate for the physician to provide the father with which of the following additional health maintenance recommendations regarding the child?
content_preview: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy since. There is no family history of serious illness. She can write her own name, is able to tie a knot, and can hop on one foot. Her father says that she has started watching television and often plays with his cell phone. She attends school regularly. She has been at the 50th percentile for both height and weight for the last 2 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The father is concerned about the effects of media exposure on his child. The physician recommends limiting screen time to approximately 1 hour daily, content monitoring by parents, and the use of a family media plan with child safety filters. At this visit, it is most appropriate for the physician to provide the father with which of the following additional health maintenance recommendations regarding the child?
hint: This guidance should also have been provided during the well-child visit at 3 years of age when toddlers can begin to perform the relevant activity.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for a child's physical safety during activities.

answers.content: Prepare separate meals for the child and fix the portion sizes of each meal
answers.explanation_why: By 1 year of age, children that are otherwise well no longer require separate food and should be eating the same meals as the parents. Healthy children can be trusted to decide how much to eat, so portion size restriction is not usually required.

answers.content: Ensure that the child is wearing a helmet and knee pads when cycling
answers.explanation_why:
Anticipatory guidance to parents of preschoolers and school-age children consists of recommendations regarding nutrition, physical development (e.g., being physically active for at least 60 minutes daily), personal hygiene (e.g., brush twice and floss once a day), sleep, media use, cognitive and social development, techniques for behavioral modification (e.g., positive reinforcement for good behavior), and, most importantly, child safety. Unintentional injury is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children over 1 year of age. Children should always wear protective gear when performing high-risk activities (e.g., cycling, climbing) and use a child safety seat appropriate for age and anthropometry when riding in a car. At 5–6 years of age, the child should be taught safe street habits and, if possible, how to swim. Children under 6 years of age should be supervised continuously during play; for children aged 6–8 years, supervision is necessary when near bodies of water or when engaged in risky activities. At home, fire alarms should be installed, fire escape plans implemented, firearms removed or stored under lock-and-key, and potentially harmful household products and tools kept out of reach.

Children should be encouraged to tell their parents if they are being bullied or face other problems at school. To minimize the likelihood of abuse, children should also be told that no adults should ever ask them to keep a secret from their parents or express interest in the child’s private parts.

answers.content: Include a compulsory daytime nap for the child in her daily routine
answers.explanation_why: While a majority of toddlers take daytime naps, only approx. 5% of children still do so by 6 years of age. At this age, daytime naps are not necessary and should not be forced, as they can delay sleep onset at night. The focus of guidance should be on establishing a routine for going to bed at night and sleeping. For children 6–12 years of age, 9–12 hours of sleep is recommended.

answers.content: Set expectations for child's academic performance at school
answers.explanation_why: It is important for parents to be involved with their children’s schooling, and they should be available to help their children with schoolwork. However, instead of the parent setting expectations for academic performance, children should be encouraged to set their own achievable goals and ask for help as needed. Good behavior should be met with reinforcement (e.g., with praise, privileges) that is focused on actions rather than immutable traits (e.g., intelligence).

answers.content: Use a rear-facing seat for the child when she is in a car
answers.explanation_why: Children under 13 years of age should always ride in the back seat, and children below 4 years of age should use rear-facing seats. A forward-facing car seat should be used for children 4–8 years of age (or earlier if the child outgrows the rear-facing car seat). A booster seat should be used for children 8–12 years of age or as soon as the child outgrows the forward-facing car seat.

question_text: A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is exclusively breastfed and receives no medications. She is at the 50^th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows no abnormalities. All routine immunizations are administered. Anticipatory guidance about feeding and development is given. At the end of the visit, the mother asks if she can continue using an oral pacifier for her daughter. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is exclusively breastfed and receives no medications. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows no abnormalities. All routine immunizations are administered. Anticipatory guidance about feeding and development is given. At the end of the visit, the mother asks if she can continue using an oral pacifier for her daughter. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: Correct pacifier use can lower the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).
learning_objective: Recognize the appropriate use and timing of pacifier introduction to prevent SIDS.

answers.content: "There are no adverse effects associated with the use of pacifiers in early infancy, and they can be used up until 5 years of age."
answers.explanation_why: Pacifier use is associated with adverse effects, such as increased risk of otitis media (especially between 2–3 years of age), and dental malocclusion (especially between 2–4 years of age).

answers.content: "Avoid using oral pacifiers until 6 months of age as it compromises breastfeeding. After 6 months, it is ok to use a pacifier."
answers.explanation_why: Although pacifiers should be avoided until breastfeeding is well established (∼ 1 month of age) to prevent difficulties, they are recommended thereafter. Additionally, pacifier use is associated with adverse effects in infants over 6 months of age, such as increased risk of otitis media.

answers.content: "Pacifiers are usually only effective in the first month of life. There are no major benefits associated with pacifier use after this age."
answers.explanation_why: Pacifier use is associated with certain benefits during a specific period of infancy. Moreover, pacifiers should be avoided before breastfeeding is well established, which usually happens within the first month of life.

answers.content: "Pacifier use has no benefit and is not recommended at any age."
answers.explanation_why: Pacifier use is associated with certain benefits (e.g., lower risk of SIDS).

answers.content: "Continue using oral pacifiers until 6 months of age, especially at the beginning of bedtime and nap time."
answers.explanation_why:
Pacifier use is recommended in infants 1–6 months of age at the start of bedtime and nap time to prevent SIDS. Nevertheless, infants should not be forced to use a pacifier, and it is not necessary to replace the pacifier if it falls out during sleep because the protective effect persists. To prevent difficulties, pacifiers should be introduced only after breastfeeding is well established. Pacifier use should be limited after 6 months of age to reduce the risk of otitis media and actively discouraged at approximately 2 years of age to prevent adverse dental effects (e.g., dental malocclusion).

Other protective factors for SIDS include a supine sleeping position, a safe sleeping environment and location (e.g., firm surface, no soft objects, cosleeping without bed-sharing), exclusive breastfeeding until 4–6 months of age, and routine immunizations.

images.title: Safe sleep practices to reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome

question_text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He was exclusively breastfed until 4 months of age and recently started eating solid foods including chicken, peanut butter, and softened sweet potatoes and carrots. He uses a pacifier while sleeping and rides in the back seat of his mother's car on a forward-facing car seat. His father has a hunting rifle that he stores unloaded and locked on a high shelf in the garage. He is at the 60^th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows no abnormalities. He can sit upright without support. He babbles. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He was exclusively breastfed until 4 months of age and recently started eating solid foods including chicken, peanut butter, and softened sweet potatoes and carrots. He uses a pacifier while sleeping and rides in the back seat of his mother's car on a forward-facing car seat. His father has a hunting rifle that he stores unloaded and locked on a high shelf in the garage. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows no abnormalities. He can sit upright without support. He babbles. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: A well-child examination should include anticipatory guidance on child safety, cognitive and social development, health, and nutrition.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate child safety recommendation for a 6-month-old during a well-child examination.

answers.content: Use rear-facing car seat until 2 years of age
answers.explanation_why:
Children under 13 years of age are required by law to ride in the back seat on age- and weight-appropriate safety seats or boosters. From birth until at least 2 years of age and no later than when they outgrow the seat's height and weight limit (usually around 4 years of age), children should ride in a federally-approved rear-facing car seat. The use of age-appropriate restraints reduces the risk of injuries and death in motor vehicle collisions. Because front-seat airbags can injure or kill children during motor vehicle collisions, car seats should never be placed in the front seat.

Other recommendations for parents of children at this age include education on oral development (e.g., teething usually begins between 6–10 months of age), nutrition, and household safety.

Prolonged pacifier use is associated with adverse effects, such as otitis media (especially at 2–3 years of age) and dental malocclusion (especially after 3 years of age). However, pacifier use during sleep can lower the risk of sudden infant death syndrome. Pacifier use may also be beneficial when breastfeeding is not possible (e.g., due to maternal illness) and to prevent a persistent finger-sucking habit. Therefore, limiting pacifier use to naptime and bedtime is recommended from 6 months of age, but it should not be routinely discouraged until approximately 2 years of age.

answers.content: Remove all guns from the home
answers.explanation_why: Firearms should be kept unloaded and locked, with ammunition stored separately, and out of children's reach (e.g., on a high shelf in the garage). Removing all guns from the home is not necessary to ensure household safety.

Although vaccines should be reviewed and administered at each well-child examination, live-attenuated vaccines are not indicated in children under the age of 9 months. The varicella vaccine is administered at 1 year of age.

answers.content: Avoid peanut butter until 1 year of age
answers.explanation_why: Certain foods (e.g., cow's milk, honey) should be avoided in children under 1 year of age. However, children can start eating solid foods including those containing peanuts at 4–6 months of age. Additionally, early introduction of allergenic foods (e.g., peanuts, eggs) can lower the risk of atopic disease and/or allergies.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 9 months
Sex Assigned at Birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: well-child visit
History of Present Illness:

patient brought by his parents for a well-child visit
mother reports the child is breastfeeding every 3 to 4 hours, is sleeping well, and has 4 to 5 wet diapers per day
a large head circumference was noted at the last well-child visit, but the patient is otherwise well

Past Medical History:

uncomplicated vaginal delivery; mother received routine prenatal care
transient neonatal jaundice that resolved spontaneously during the first 2 weeks of life

Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
mother and father: alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial History:

both parents actively engaged in the child's care
child crawls, smiles, and recognizes familiar faces and toys 

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Lt
Wt
BMI
Head circumference

37.0°C
(98.6°F)

120/min
45/min
90/60 mm Hg
–

72 cm
(2 ft 4 in)
50th %ile

8.5 kg
(19 lb)
50th %ile

–
48 cm (1 ft 7 in)
97th %ile

Appearance: alert; responsive; no acute distress; appears well nourished
Skin: no rashes
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs 
Abdominal: soft, nontender, nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; 
Genitourinary: descended testicles
Extremities: no edema or deformities; brachial and femoral pulses palpable bilaterally and equal in amplitude
Neurologic: anterior fontanelle open and soft; posterior fontanelle closed; cranial nerves intact; muscle tone is normal bilaterally; deep tendon reflexes symmetrical; primitive reflexes are appropriate for age

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 9 months Sex Assigned at Birth: M Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: well-child visit History of Present Illness: patient brought by his parents for a well-child visit mother reports the child is breastfeeding every 3 to 4 hours, is sleeping well, and has 4 to 5 wet diapers per day a large head circumference was noted at the last well-child visit, but the patient is otherwise well Past Medical History: uncomplicated vaginal delivery; mother received routine prenatal care transient neonatal jaundice that resolved spontaneously during the first 2 weeks of life Medications: none Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: mother and father: alive with no chronic conditions Psychosocial History: both parents actively engaged in the child's care child crawls, smiles, and recognizes familiar faces and toys Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Lt Wt BMI Head circumference 37.0°C(98.6°F) 120/min 45/min 90/60 mm Hg – 72 cm(2 ft 4 in)50th %ile 8.5 kg(19 lb)50th %ile – 48 cm (1 ft 7 in)97th %ile Appearance: alert; responsive; no acute distress; appears well nourished Skin: no rashes Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: soft, nontender, nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; Genitourinary: descended testicles Extremities: no edema or deformities; brachial and femoral pulses palpable bilaterally and equal in amplitude Neurologic: anterior fontanelle open and soft; posterior fontanelle closed; cranial nerves intact; muscle tone is normal bilaterally; deep tendon reflexes symmetrical; primitive reflexes are appropriate for age Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?
hint: A head circumference 2 standard deviations above the mean (i.e., ≥ 97^th percentile) suggests macrocephaly.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate evaluation in a child with macrocephaly.

answers.explanation_why: Measuring both parents' occipitofrontal head circumferences and plotting them on a Weaver curve is the most appropriate next step in patients with macrocephaly who meet all of the following criteria: normal developmental milestones, normal neurological examination, no clinical features of a syndrome, and no family history of neurological abnormalities. If the child's standard score for head circumference is within the range of the average parental standard score on the Weaver curve, then benign familial macrocephaly is the most likely diagnosis, and no additional neuroimaging or treatment are required.
This patient likely has a benign cause of macrocephaly, but an additional step is necessary to confirm this benign cause.

Ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality in children with open fontanelle because it does not involve radiation or require sedation. Neuroimaging should be performed if an expanding lesion is suspected and/or in children with developmental delay and no clinical features of a syndrome. This patient does not meet these criteria, and another step in evaluation is therefore more appropriate at this time.

A skeletal survey exposes children to radiation and is only indicated in cases where physical abuse is suspected, e.g., features of subdural hematoma. This patient does not present with features that suggest abuse, and another step in evaluation is therefore more appropriate at this time.

CT scan of the head may be indicated in children with closed fontanelles and neurological abnormalities and/or in those with an acute condition (e.g., suspected obstructive hydrocephalus). This patient does not meet these criteria, and another step in evaluation is therefore more appropriate at this time.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine check-up. She feels well. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Her mother had hypertension; there is no family history of osteoporosis. She experienced menopause at age 52. She drinks a glass of wine on holidays, walks her dog outdoors for 1 hour daily, and has never smoked. Her diet includes dairy, leafy green vegetables, and salmon. Physical examination and BMI findings are normal. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, metabolic panel, serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D, and thyroid-stimulating hormone, show no abnormalities. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) has never been performed. She is interested in “doing whatever I can to keep my bones healthy.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine check-up. She feels well. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Her mother had hypertension; there is no family history of osteoporosis. She experienced menopause at age 52. She drinks a glass of wine on holidays, walks her dog outdoors for 1 hour daily, and has never smoked. Her diet includes dairy, leafy green vegetables, and salmon. Physical examination and BMI findings are normal. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, metabolic panel, serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D, and thyroid-stimulating hormone, show no abnormalities. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) has never been performed. She is interested in “doing whatever I can to keep my bones healthy.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Risk factors for osteoporosis include low body weight, smoking, a family history of osteoporosis, previous fractures, and long-term corticosteroid use.
learning_objective: Recognize vitamin D and calcium needs of postmenopausal  women with no risk factors.

answers.content: Recommend dietary intake of calcium and vitamin D
answers.explanation_why:
Dietary and lifestyle measures are the mainstay of osteoporosis prevention in postmenopausal women under 65 without risk factors. This includes an optimized intake of calcium and vitamin D, with recommended daily intakes of 1000–1200 mg of calcium and 800–1000 IU of vitamin D. Dietary sources are preferred over supplements unless a deficiency is present. Other preventive measures include physical exercise (e.g., strength training), smoking cessation, and limiting alcohol intake.

Screening for osteoporosis is indicated in women ≥ 65 years and those with risk factors (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use).

answers.content: Start 2000 IU daily oral vitamin D supplement
answers.explanation_why: High-dose vitamin D supplementation is reserved for patients with confirmed vitamin D deficiency and those at an increased risk of deficiency (e.g., due to malabsorption, minimal sun exposure). This patient’s vitamin D level is normal, and she gets regular sun exposure and has a balanced diet that includes food rich in vitamin D (e.g., salmon). Excess supplementation can increase the risk for adverse effects such as hypercalcemia and nephrolithiasis.

Bisphosphonates are indicated for the treatment of confirmed osteoporosis and in patients with osteopenia who are at increased risk of major osteoporotic fracture in the next 10 years. Bisphosphonates are not used for the primary prevention of osteoporosis.

Estrogen replacement therapy may reduce bone loss and fracture risk but is not recommended for the primary prevention of osteoporosis in asymptomatic postmenopausal women due to the increased risk for breast cancer, thromboembolism, and cardiovascular events.

DXA screening is recommended for women aged 65 or older and may be considered in younger women with significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., low body weight, smoking, family history of osteoporosis). At 62 years of age, with no risk factors, this patient does not meet the criteria for DXA screening.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine examination. She recently began a new job as a middle school science teacher. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She has never traveled outside the United States, has no known drug allergies, and has never smoked or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. The patient is sexually active with her husband and is not pregnant. Her last tetanus-containing vaccine was at age 12 years. She received all childhood vaccinations, including the full series for measles, mumps, and rubella. She had chickenpox at 7 years of age and received the human papillomavirus vaccine series in her early 20s. Her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination recommendation at this visit?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine examination. She recently began a new job as a middle school science teacher. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She has never traveled outside the United States, has no known drug allergies, and has never smoked or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. The patient is sexually active with her husband and is not pregnant. Her last tetanus-containing vaccine was at age 12 years. She received all childhood vaccinations, including the full series for measles, mumps, and rubella. She had chickenpox at 7 years of age and received the human papillomavirus vaccine series in her early 20s. Her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination recommendation at this visit?
learning_objective: Recognize appropriate vaccination recommendations for healthy adults.

answers.explanation_why: Routine hepatitis B immunization was implemented for all infants in the United States in 1991. This 25-year-old patient was born after universal childhood hepatitis B immunization became standard practice; therefore, she likely received the full hepatitis B vaccine series in early childhood and does not require catch-up vaccination. Hepatitis B vaccine boosters are indicated only in high-risk patients (e.g., occupational exposure, immunocompromise, those receiving hemodialysis) who are nonimmune according to HBV serology (HBsAb < 10 IU/mL).

Meningococcal vaccination is recommended for individuals at risk for meningococcal infections (e.g., those with asplenia or complement deficiencies, college students living in dormitories, military recruits). Middle school teachers do not require routine meningococcal vaccination unless they have other risk factors.

The recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended for adults ≥ 50 years of age and immunocompromised individuals ≥ 19 years of age, regardless of prior varicella infection or shingles history. This patient is only 25 years of age and is not immunocompromised, so zoster vaccination is not indicated at this time.

Pneumococcal vaccination is indicated for individuals ≥ 50 years of age and for those aged 19–49 years with risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease (e.g., immunocompromise, asplenia). This is a healthy 25-year-old patient with no risk factors requiring pneumococcal vaccination.

answers.content: Administer tetanus, diphtheria, acellular pertussis vaccine
answers.explanation_why:
A single dose of tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is recommended for all adults who have not previously received it or whose last dose was in adolescence. After initial Tdap vaccination, all patients should receive tetanus-diphtheria vaccine or Tdap boosters every 10 years. This patient’s last tetanus-containing vaccine was at 12 years of age, so she is overdue for a Tdap booster. As a middle school teacher, protection against pertussis is especially important to prevent transmission to vulnerable children. Tdap also maintains immunity against diphtheria, which can cause severe illness.

Annual influenza vaccination is also recommended for all adults, including this patient, but Tdap is the most urgent vaccination in this scenario.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine check-up before starting a new job. She has no current concerns. Her last routine check-up was 3 years ago, and she has not seen a doctor since. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She exercises regularly and has a balanced diet. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her father was diagnosed with hypertension at age 52. Her maternal grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 72. She has never smoked tobacco or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (141 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine check-up before starting a new job. She has no current concerns. Her last routine check-up was 3 years ago, and she has not seen a doctor since. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She exercises regularly and has a balanced diet. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her father was diagnosed with hypertension at age 52. Her maternal grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 72. She has never smoked tobacco or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (141 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
hint: Screening recommendations for women differ by age and risk factors.
learning_objective: Recognize appropriate preventive health screenings for asymptomatic adults aged 20 to 35 years.

answers.explanation_why: While hypertension screening is recommended for all adults starting at 18 years of age, this is typically done with office-based blood pressure measurements rather than ambulatory monitoring, which is reserved for suspected white coat hypertension or masked hypertension. This 23-year-old patient with normal blood pressure (116/74 mm Hg) and no risk factors should have routine hypertension screening every 3–5 years using standard office measurements.

Screening for diabetes using fasting plasma glucose is recommended for adults aged 35–70 years with overweight or obesity, or for younger individuals with additional risk factors (e.g., a family history of diabetes, hypertension, or signs of insulin resistance). As this patient is 23 years of age, has a normal BMI, and no identifiable risk factors, fasting glucose screening is not currently indicated.

Pap smear and/or HPV testing detect precancerous and cancerous cervical changes, allowing early intervention to prevent progression to cervical cancer. Both the American Cancer Society (ACS) and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening, although their starting ages and intervals differ slightly. The USPSTF advises beginning at age 21 with Pap smear alone every 3 years until age 29, and for individuals aged 30–65 years, either primary HPV testing every 5 years, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years, or Pap smear alone every 3 years. In contrast, recent guidelines from the ACS, the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology, and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend starting primary HPV testing every 5 years at age 25, with HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years as an alternative, and Pap smear alone every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable. As this patient is 23 years of age, asymptomatic, and up-to-date with other preventive screenings, she should undergo cervical cancer screening with a Pap smear.

Lipid panel testing is recommended for adults starting at 20 years of age for cardiovascular risk assessment. For individuals with a low risk and a normal lipid profile, repeat screening is generally advised every 4 to 6 years. As this patient had a routine check-up 3 years ago, is healthy, has a normal BMI, and has no cardiovascular risk factors, lipid testing is not currently indicated.

Mammography is recommended for breast cancer screening starting at age 40–50 years, depending on guidelines, and is not indicated for asymptomatic women under 40 years of age without high-risk conditions for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation). For women with a family history of breast cancer, it is generally recommended to start breast cancer screening 10 years before the age of the earliest diagnosis in the family, but not before the age of 30 years.

Individuals with a genetic predisposition to breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation) should begin screening between the ages of 25 and 29 years. For individuals aged ≤ 29 years, breast examination every 6–12 months and annual breast MRI are recommended.
